column3: Providers shall maintain accurate records of all externally-facing systems.
column5: VCF/TCP provides API integration support for third-party tools including IT asset management (ITAM) systems, configuration management databases (CMDB), and security assessment tools. The VCF Operations suite, which includes VCF Operations for Networks, VCF Operations for Logs, and VCF Operations, works with VMware vDefend to deliver security assessment and continuous monitoring. VCF Operations for Networks specifically discovers and maps all externally-facing systems and their traffic flows, providing a real-time view of the infrastructure and its dependencies. Security teams can generate custom reports, export data, and automate tasks using product interfaces, PowerCLI, and APIs. VCF/TCP supports VMware APIs for Data Protection (VADP) for third-party backup integration.

column3: Security testing on externally-facing systems, excluding CPE, should normally be performed at least every two years, and in any case shortly after a significant change occurs.
column5: While the formal process of security testing is an organizational responsibility, VCF/TCP provides integrated tools to support this requirement. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall includes an Intrusion Detection System/Intrusion Prevention System (IDS/IPS) that performs continuous assessment of externally-facing systems. This engine uses signature-based detection to identify known attack patterns and anomaly-based detection to identify suspicious activity that could indicate an unknown or zero-day threat. This provides a continuous, automated layer of security testing in addition to periodic manual assessments.

column3: Equipment in the exposed edge shall not host sensitive data or security critical functions.
column5: This is primarily an architectural and organizational policy that VCF/TCP directly enables. VCF/TCP's Workload Domain architecture allows providers to create logically and often physically separate infrastructure pools. A provider would deploy their "exposed edge" services into a dedicated Edge Workload Domain, while ensuring that "security critical functions" (like vCenter, NSX Manager, and VCF Operations) reside in the separate, highly secured Management Domain. VMware vDefend and NSX then enforce strict, "default-deny" firewall policies to isolate the Management Domain, preventing the edge from accessing or hosting sensitive data and functions.

column3: Physical and logical separation shall be implemented between the exposed edge and security critical functions. Note that this measure may not be necessary once datasets and functions can be cryptographically-protected from compromise.
column5: VCF/TCP achieves this separation using a multi-layered approach. Logical separation is enforced by the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall, which applies distributed, stateful firewalling and zero-trust policies to isolate the exposed edge from critical functions, regardless of their physical location. Physical separation is enabled through the Workload Domain architecture. Providers can deploy critical functions (like the VCF Management Domain) on a dedicated cluster of hosts, while edge services run on a separate physical cluster, ensuring no shared hardware or "blast radius."

column3: Security boundaries shall exist between the exposed edge and critical or sensitive functions that implement protective measures.
column5: VCF/TCP establishes robust security boundaries using VMware vDefend and NSX Edge Gateways. The vDefend Gateway Firewall acts as the primary North-South security boundary, providing stateful inspection, NAT, and VPN capabilities. Behind this, the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall (DFW) provides granular, east-west firewalling, creating a "default-deny" internal security boundary that isolates every workload. This ensures that even if the edge is compromised, lateral movement to critical functions is blocked by this internal boundary.

column3: Equipment in the exposed edge shall not be able to impact operation or routing within the core network. As an example, the exposed edge shall not be a PE-node within the provider's IP Core.
column5: This is an architectural principle that VCF/TCP's networking model supports. The "exposed edge" services (e.g., customer-facing VMs or CNFs) run as workloads on the VCF/TCP; they are not VCF/TCP's routing infrastructure itself. VCF/TCP's core network routing is managed by NSX Edge Nodes, which act as the provider's PE-nodes (or connect to them). These Edge Nodes are part of the secured infrastructure, logically separate from the workloads. By using vDefend firewall rules, the provider can ensure that workloads in the exposed edge domain cannot access or interact with the management interfaces of the NSX Edge Nodes, preventing them from impacting core network routing.

column3: Privileged user access rights shall be regularly reviewed and updated as part of business-as-usual management. This shall include updating privileged user rights in line with any relevant changes to roles and responsibilities within the organisation.
column5: While the business process for performing access reviews is an organizational responsibility, VCF/TCP provides the centralized visibility and logging required to conduct them effectively. VCF SSO and identity federation centralize authentication, allowing administrators to review all assigned roles and permissions for users and groups directly within the vCenter Client. To support this review, the VCF Operations Audit Events framework and VCF Operations for Logs capture detailed information on privileged user activity, including logins, configuration changes, and API calls. This data can be forwarded to external SIEM systems or analyzed within VCF Operations to generate reports, enabling auditors to verify that user access aligns with their documented roles and responsibilities.

column3: All privileged access shall be logged.
column5: VCF/TCP logs all privileged access. VCF SSO logs all successful and failed authentication attempts. The VCF Operations Audit Events framework and Kubernetes audit logging then capture all subsequent privileged actions, including API calls, configuration modifications, and user-driven tasks. These logs are attributable to unique users and can be viewed in the vSphere Client or forwarded via syslog to VCF Operations for Logs for centralized retention and analysis.

column3: Privileged access shall be via secure, encrypted and authenticated protocols whenever technically viable.
column5: VCF/TCP enforces this for all privileged access. All management interfaces, including the vCenter Client, VCF Operations console, and all component APIs, use Transport Layer Security (TLS 1.3/1.2) by default, ensuring all administrative traffic is encrypted. Authentication is centralized via VCF SSO, which federates with secure identity providers and can enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA). Direct access to ESX hosts is eliminated in favor of this centralized, encrypted, and authenticated model.

column3: Management protocols that are not required shall be disabled on all network functions and equipment.
column5: VCF/TCP enforces this by default. Management components are deployed in a "secure-by-default" configuration where unrequired services and protocols are disabled. This baseline is defined and monitored by VCF/TCP's compliance capabilities, which check against standards like the VMware Security Configuration Guide. Furthermore, the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall applies a "default-deny" policy to management components, ensuring that even if a protocol were enabled, it would be blocked at the network layer unless explicitly permitted.

column3: Default passwords shall be changed upon initialisation of the device or service and before its use for the provision of the relevant network of service.
column5: VCF/TCP does not use generic, "well-known" default passwords. The requirement to change passwords upon initialization is enforced as a mandatory step in the deployment process. When you deploy VCF/TCP or its components, you must either specify a strong, unique password for each component account or have the system auto-generate a complex, random password. No default credentials are left on the device after this initial setup. After deployment, these passwords can be centrally managed, rotated, and remediated via the VCF Operations console. Password policies, such as complexity, history, and timeouts, are enforced by VCF SSO or can be federated to an external identity provider.

column3: The infrastructure used to support a provider's network shall be the responsibility of the provider, or another entity that adheres to the regulations, measures and oversight as they apply to the provider (such as a third party supplier with whom the provider has a contractual relationship). Where the provider or other entity adhering to the regulations has responsibility, this responsibility shall include retaining oversight of the management of that infrastructure (including sight of management activities, personnel granted management access, and management processes).
column5: While the provider retains responsibility, VCF/TCP provides the necessary tools to maintain technical oversight. The VCF Operations suite, including VCF Operations, VCF Operations for Logs, and VCF Operations for Networks, delivers a centralized dashboard for monitoring infrastructure health, security, and configuration. This unified view, combined with real-time alerts and comprehensive audit logging, gives the provider the complete oversight required to manage VCF/TCP.

column3: Providers shall understand how incoming signalling arrives into their network, and outgoing signalling leaves their network. Specifically, the interfaces over which signalling enters and leaves the network, and the equipment which sends and processes external signalling.
column5: VCF/TCP provides specific tools to help providers understand their signalling flows. VCF Operations for Networks is designed to discover and map all network traffic, providing a visual representation of how signalling arrives, traverses VCF/TCP, and leaves the network. It identifies the interfaces, protocols, and equipment (virtual or physical) involved in the flow. This is complemented by VMware vDefend, which provides stateful firewalling and logging at the logical edge and for all internal workloads, allowing for granular monitoring and control of these identified signalling paths.

column3: Providers shall have an appropriate understanding of what network equipment could be impacted by malicious signalling.
column5: With VCF/TCP, the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall can be implemented to protect every traffic flow inside the data center with a stateful firewall, allowing only necessary traffic flows, which helps in mitigating malicious activity. Administrators need to know how network equipment facilitates or complicates this process. Through the VCF Operations for Networks component, VCF/TCP provides visibility into virtual network traffic, helping detect network traffic patterns and potential risks. This requires a good understanding of how network equipment interacts with the monitoring tools.

column3: Providers shall have an appropriate understanding of what network and user data could be compromised through malicious signalling.
column5: VCF/TCP provides tools to help providers understand and mitigate data compromise from malicious signalling. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall can be implemented to apply zero-trust policies, protecting every traffic flow inside the data center and allowing only necessary communication, which helps mitigate malicious activity. This is complemented by VCF Operations for Networks, which provides deep visibility into virtual network traffic, helping administrators detect anomalous patterns and understand potential risks to network and user data.

column3: Providers shall understand who they directly connect with over the signalling network and operate on the principle that incoming signals are from untrusted networks.
column5: VCF/TCP provides the tools to enforce a "zero-trust" model for all connections, as required by this measure. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall applies stateful, "default-deny" firewalling to every workload, ensuring that trust is never assumed based on network location. To help providers "understand who they directly connect with," VCF Operations for Networks can visualize all traffic flows, mapping out dependencies and connections between internal workloads and external entities, which is essential for defining and auditing security policies.

column3: At edge signalling nodes, providers shall block any incoming message using any source address internal to the provider's network.
column5: VCF/TCP providers can implement this at their network edge using the vDefend Gateway Firewall. An explicit "default-deny" ingress rule can be created on the external-facing interface to drop any traffic that has a source IP address matching the provider's internal address ranges, preventing this form of source address spoofing.

column3: Trust shall not be assumed based on the source of any incoming message. For example, UK source addresses (e.g. +44 global titles in SS7) shall not be assumed to be trusted and shall not be allowed by default.
column5: This measure describes the zero-trust security model, which is a foundational principle of VCF/TCP's design. VCF/TCP operates on the basis that no traffic is trusted by default, regardless of its source. This is enforced by the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall, which applies distributed, stateful firewalling to every workload. Security policies are based on workload identity, not just IP addresses, ensuring that even traffic from a "trusted" internal segment must be explicitly permitted to communicate with a critical function.

column3: Where the signalling message is protected by end-to-end authentication, risk decisions and associated security controls may be determined based upon the authenticated source.
column5: The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall can enforce security policies based on workload identity, which can be linked to an authenticated source. Furthermore, providers can deploy specialized NFs (as VNFs or CNFs) on the VCF/TCP that perform protocol-level authentication. VMware vDefend can then enforce security decisions, such as applying specific firewall policies or directing traffic, based on the validated status provided by these functions.

column3: Where providers allow others to use number ranges that have been allocated to them (e.g. GTs, IMSIs), they remain responsible for the activity related to that number range, and any further security implications. This does not apply in the case of MSISDNs shared through MNP.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: Any outgoing message that uses a source address that should not transit or leave the provider's network shall not be permitted to leave the provider's network.
column5: VCF/TCP providers can enforce this egress filtering policy using the vDefend Gateway Firewall. By configuring stateful egress rules, any outbound traffic from the provider's network that has an invalid source address (e.g., an address that should not be routable externally) can be identified, logged, and dropped before it leaves the logical edge of the network.

column3: Networks shall only send outgoing signalling in support of services permitted by the recipient. Guidance on what the GSMA has defined as permitted services is set out within Section 5 of GSMA's charging and accounting principles and Section 10 of GSMA's interconnection and interworking charging principles.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: External BGP updates shall be monitored for evidence of misuse.
column5: VCF Operations for Networks provides comprehensive network traffic monitoring and can track BGP routing updates. VCF/TCP captures and visualizes routing changes, providing administrators with visibility into BGP behavior. This monitoring data can be integrated with VCF Operations for Logs for centralized analysis and alerting on suspicious BGP activity patterns.

column3: Any BGP misuse that impacts a provider's network or services shall be mitigated in a timely manner, and at least within 12 hours whenever technically possible.
column5: While BGP policy management is an organizational responsibility, VCF/TCP provides tools to support rapid response. VCF Operations for Networks delivers real-time visibility into routing changes, enabling rapid detection of BGP anomalies. VMware vDefend Gateway Firewall and NSX routing policies can be updated through APIs or the management interface to block malicious routes or traffic patterns within minutes of detection.

column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: Providers shall implement ingress and egress route filtering.
column5: VCF/TCP implements ingress and egress route filtering primarily through NSX and BGP filtering, allowing for granular control over network traffic and enhancing security within the VCF/TCP.

column3: Providers shall adopt and implement mechanisms that prevent IP address spoofing.
column5: Platform, particularly through its integration with NSX's SpoofGuard, offers mechanisms to address IP spoofing on the data plane.

column3: End-users shall not be able to spoof IPs over the data plane (e.g. in line with BCP38).
column5: VCF/TCP provides robust mechanisms to prevent IP spoofing on the data plane, directly aligning with BCP38 principles. This is primarily achieved through NSX SpoofGuard and the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall. NSX SpoofGuard is a data plane security feature that creates and maintains a trusted table of IP, MAC, and vNIC port bindings. It actively monitors traffic from virtual machines and blocks any packets that do not match these approved and verified bindings. This capability is complemented by the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall, which uses identity-based firewalling to enforce zero-trust security policies. Spoofed traffic that violates these granular, stateful policies is automatically dropped, preventing lateral movement. At the network edge, the vDefend Gateway Firewall can be configured to filter ingress and egress traffic, further ensuring that packets with spoofed source addresses are blocked.

column3: The provider shall ensure the risks included in Regulation 7(3) are assessed prior to contract, and this assessment is documented. This assessment shall inform both risk management and procurement processes.

column3: Providers shall only store SIM credentials and SIM transport keys within secured systems that ensure data integrity and prevent 'read' access to key material.
column5: This measure relates to provider-specific functions (SIMs). VCF provides the secure infrastructure to host these functions. A provider's credentialing system can be run as an encrypted virtual machine (VM Encryption) with a virtual Trusted Platform Module (vTPM). This vTPM provides a hardware-backed secure storage equivalent for the VM to store keys and secrets, preventing their extraction. The underlying physical ESX hosts can also use hardware TPMs to store their own configuration encryption keys, ensuring keys are not available in cleartext on disk.

column3: Providers shall review the security of existing SIM cards on an annual basis, including the supplier, the protection of keys, the algorithms used by the SIM, and the applets provisioned and running on SIMs.

However, Broadcom strives to achieve a high level of information protection standards. Relevant policies for information security have been established that are in line with Broadcom's corporate objectives and in accordance with business requirements, relevant laws and regulations, contracts, and current or projected security threats. Based on international standards ISO/IEC 27001 and consistent with industry-accepted practices and security frameworks, Broadcom information security policies define requirements for the protection of Broadcom information and its information systems.

column3: Security changes shall be prioritised and postponements of security changes shall be minimised. Where security changes are postponed, these may need to be recorded as a business risk as appropriate.
column5: VCF/TCP provides a suite of integrated lifecycle management tools that directly enable providers to prioritize and deploy security changes. Broadcom maintains a security advisory system to inform customers of updates, and the VCF Operations console provides built-in alerts for security vulnerabilities and available patches, allowing providers to identify and prioritize critical changes. VCF Operations orchestration and vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) centralize and automate the update process for the entire stack. Features like pre-update validation, component interdependency management, and staged rollouts allow for controlled deployment. This, combined with zero-downtime maintenance capabilities (using Distributed Resource Scheduler) and Live Patching, empowers providers to apply high-priority security changes rapidly and safely, minimizing the need for postponement and reducing the associated risk.

column3: Providers shall maintain read-only backups of their infrastructure and information and shall be able to restore them. The backups should contain the information necessary to maintain the normal operation of the public electronic communications network or public electronic communications service.
column5: VCF/TCP leverages built-in backup features for core management components like VCF Operations, vCenter Server Appliance, and NSX Manager. These backups capture the configuration and state of VCF/TCP. VMware Telco Cloud Platform extends this by also backing up configurations of orchestration layers (e.g., VMware Telco Cloud Automation - TCA, OpenStack controllers, Kubernetes etcd databases) and crucial VNF/CNF definitions/templates. It is the provider's responsibility to integrate these with secure, immutable external storage solutions and validate the restoration process.

column3: Providers shall have clear, exercised and implemented processes for managing security incidents, at varying levels of severity.
column5: While the development of an incident response process is an organizational responsibility, VCF/TCP provides a suite of tools for detection, containment, and automated response. VCF Operations and VMware vDefend (with its IDS/IPS) detect threats and can trigger alerts. For investigation, analysts can use VCF Operations for Networks to visualize the incident's network traffic and application dependencies, and VCF Operations for Logs to correlate logs from all VCF/TCP components. VCF Automation can then consume these alerts to orchestrate a formal response runbook, such as automatically quarantining the workload, taking a forensic snapshot, and notifying the incident response team.

column3: Providers shall perform a root-cause analysis of all security incidents. Outcomes of this analysis shall be escalated to an appropriate level, which may include the provider's board.
column5: While the analysis itself is an organizational process, VCF/TCP provides the critical, centralized audit trail required to perform it. VCF Operations for Logs collects and securely stores all relevant logs from every VCF/TCP component, including ESX, vCenter, and NSX. More importantly, the VCF Operations Audit Events framework and Kubernetes audit logging capture all privileged actions, API calls, and configuration modifications, attributing them to a unique user. This queryable, immutable log data is the foundation for any post-incident root-cause analysis.

column3: For significant incidents, providers shall share the high-level lessons learned with other providers, so far as is appropriate and proportionate.

column3: Lessons learned from previous security incidents shall be used to inform the security of new products and services.

column3: Non-persistent credentials (e.g. username and password authentication) shall be stored in a centralised service with appropriate role-based access control which shall be updated in line with any relevant changes to roles and responsibilities within the organisation.
column5: VCF/TCP meets this requirement by default. All user credentials for VCF/TCP are managed by VCF SSO, which acts as the centralized authentication service. VCF SSO integrates with identity sources like Active Directory or LDAP, centralizing credential management. All permissions are then enforced through granular role-based access control (RBAC), allowing roles to be updated in line with organizational changes without changing the underlying credential store.

column3: Privileged access shall be via accounts with unique user ID and authentication credentials for each user and these shall not be shared.
column5: This is a foundational principle of VCF/TCP's access model. VCF SSO requires each administrator to authenticate with their own unique user ID, typically federated from an enterprise directory like Active Directory. This ensures all privileged actions, which are logged by the VCF Operations Audit Events framework, are traceable to a specific, unique individual, eliminating the need for shared administrative accounts.

column3: For accounts capable of making changes to security critical functions, the following measures shall be adopted relating to multi-factor authentication: (a) the second factor shall be locally generated, and not be transmitted; and (b) the multi-factor authentication mechanism shall be independent of the provider's network and PAW. Soft tokens (e.g. authenticator apps) may be used.
column5: VCF/TCP supports this through identity federation. VCF SSO integrates with modern identity providers (such as Okta, Ping, ADFS) using standard protocols like SAML 2.0 and OIDC. This allows the provider to enforce their enterprise-wide MFA policy, which typically uses locally generated soft tokens (e.g., authenticator apps) or hardware tokens that are independent of the provider's network, to secure all privileged access to the VCF/TCP.

column3: All break-glass privileged user accounts must have unique, strong credentials per individual piece of network equipment.
column5: VCF/TCP provides the centralized tools to manage and secure break-glass privileged accounts, fulfilling the requirement for unique credentials per device. The VCF Operations console features unified password management for all VCF components. This allows an administrator to update and remediate passwords for each piece of network equipment, such as setting unique passwords for each individual ESX host, vCenter instance, or NSX Manager. This feature gives administrators a consolidated view of all break-glass accounts, their current status, and any remediation needs, ensuring all components maintain their required strength and uniqueness from a single, secure console.

column3: Default and hardcoded accounts shall be disabled.
column5: VCF/TCP does not use generic, "well-known" default passwords. While some service accounts are required for functionality, their passwords are set at deployment to either an administrator-specified or a randomly-generated strong value. These passwords can then be centrally managed, rotated, and remediated using the VCF Operations console's unified password management feature. This allows administrators to enforce password policies and set unique, strong credentials for each individual ESX host and management component, eliminating shared or default credentials.

column3: Any incoming or outgoing message type that should not be sent over international or external signalling networks shall be blocked at the logical edge of the provider's network. For example, GSMA CAT 1 messages shall be blocked for SS7 networks, and equivalent messages shall be blocked for other signalling protocols such as Diameter, GTP, Interconnect and SS7/SIGTRAN.
column5: VMware vDefend provides the Layer 7 inspection capabilities required to block specific message types at the network edge. Using its application-aware security policies and Distributed Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) engine, providers can create rules that identify and block specific protocols or message signatures (like GSMA CAT 1) that should not traverse an external interconnect, while permitting legitimate traffic.

column3: When sent over signalling networks, the external exposure of customer data, customer identifiers and network topology information shall be minimised.
column5: VCF/TCP helps providers minimize this exposure through network isolation. By using a multi-tiered network architecture with vDefend, providers can create demilitarized zones (DMZs) where publicly accessible services are segregated from the internal network. This ensures that sensitive customer data and network topology information, which reside in the secured internal zones, are never directly exposed to the external signalling network.

column3: Providers shall have in place the means for recipients of their BGP routing updates to validate that the BGP routing update originated from the legitimate owner.
column5: VCF/TCP, through its NSX component, provides VCF/TCP's BGP routing capabilities. NSX Edge Nodes act as BGP routers that peer with external networks. To help validate incoming BGP routing updates, providers can configure BGP route filtering on these NSX Edge Nodes. This allows for the creation of rules that can accept or deny prefixes based on specific criteria, which is a foundational component of validating route origins.

column3: Where the necessary information is available, providers shall validate that any BGP route updates they receive have originated from the legitimate owner.
column5:
VCF/TCP provides a robust, scalable, and resilient environment on which provider can deploy the necessary components to secure its BGP operations. NSX Edge Nodes can be configured as highly available BGP routers that peer with Providers' upstream providers and other networks. These are the components that would originate Providers' BGP updates.
In VCF Operations for networks you can see various information on BGP neighbors. You can view the BGP neighbors of an NSX edge or a logical router.

column3: During procurement of equipment, prior to contract award, providers shall ensure the security functionality of all equipment has been tested.
column5: Broadcom conducts regular and systematic threat assessment and security testing of its products. As new features are designed and developed, they undergo security design reviews and threat modeling based on their security sensitivity and are tested for vulnerabilities. Major updates are subject to annual penetration testing, while incremental features are reviewed and tested for security as part of the continuous Secure Development Lifecycle (SDL). This testing involves both manual techniques and automated scanners to identify various weaknesses (e.g., OWASP Top 10 and SANS Top 25), as well as specialized fuzzing techniques for applicable modules (like API, network and http interfaces). While most Broadcom security testing is conducted using in house security engineering resources, at times Broadcom may choose to engage a third-party vendor to perform additional testing. This engagement is performed using internal VMware security resources.

When you deploy VCF/TCP or its components, you must either specify a strong, unique password for each component account or have the system auto-generate a complex, random password. No default credentials are left on the device after this initial setup. After deployment, these passwords can be centrally managed, rotated, and remediated via the VCF Operations console. Password policies, such as complexity, history, and timeouts, are enforced by VCF SSO or can be federated to an external identity provider.

The default configuration of VMware products disables insecure management protocols, makes use of secure APIs and communication channels instead of Telnet, and employs HTTP over TLS (HTTPS). Some components respond to HTTP (80/tcp) in order to redirect the client to HTTPS (443/tcp), and that port can be blocked externally if  desired.

column3: Providers shall ensure that all security-relevant logging is enabled on all network equipment and sent to the network logging systems.
column5:
VMware vSphere provides comprehensive tools to track system events and user actions for monitoring and security. Basic logs are viewable through the Tasks and Events tab in the vSphere Client. This helps track changes and troubleshoot issues. For detailed analysis, VCF Operations for Logs collects logs from vCenter Server and ESX hosts. It offers advanced dashboards and analytics for deeper insights.

The VCF Operations Audit Events framework captures VCF/TCP interactions including user logins and logouts, capability checks, and configuration modifications across vSphere, vSAN, and NSX resources. This framework enhances transparency, control, and accountability by registering each action as an event. It enables detection of suspicious access patterns and policy violations while providing user accountability through detailed activity tracking.

ESX hosts maintain local logging with configurable retention and rotation policies for forensic purposes. vCenter Server provides database retention policies with automated cleanup based on age or database size. API audit logging captures REST API calls, SDK usage, and PowerCLI commands with user attribution. Storage operation logging tracks vSAN operations, datastore actions, and storage policy changes. NSX-T maintains audit trails for all network configuration changes including firewall rules, segments, and routing modifications.

Platform allows configuration of syslog to forward logs to up to three syslog forwarding targets using various protocols. Log forwarding supports TLS encryption to ensure confidentiality in transit. VCF Operations for Logs provides centralized log retention policies configurable by log type, source, and compliance requirements. Certificate lifecycle events including generation, renewal, revocation, and expiration are logged for security tracking. Time synchronization audit captures NTP events and drift corrections for forensic accuracy.

vSphere High Availability (HA) maintains detailed logs of all failover operations, host isolation events, and admission control decisions for audit trail purposes. VMware Live Site Recovery maintains detailed logs of all recovery operations, protection group changes, and recovery plan executions.

Kubernetes audit logging captures all API calls to the vSphere Supervisor. This includes namespace operations, pod deployments, and role-based access control (RBAC) changes. It provides complete visibility into container platform activities. Authentication events are logged for all identity sources. This includes successful and failed login attempts, password changes, and permission modifications through vCenter Single Sign-On.

vDefend provides Layer 7 traffic statistics with detailed logging of packet counts, flow statistics, protocol breakdowns, and CPU usage across cores for forensic analysis. vDefend Intrusion Detection System/Intrusion Prevention System (IDS/IPS) event correlation enables advanced event generation from custom signatures with detailed metadata for security investigations. This includes signature severity levels and threat categories.

Platform maintains comprehensive audit trails for all configuration changes and supports rollback capabilities. Change management extends to Kubernetes environments through vSphere Namespaces. Resource limits, storage policies, and access permissions require appropriate approvals before modification. VCF tracks all changes to namespace configurations, container deployments, and Kubernetes cluster lifecycle operations through unified audit logging.

column3: Providers shall prioritise critical security patches over functionality upgrades wherever possible.

This allows providers to treat the vulnerability as an immediate priority while using the VCF Operations orchestration and vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) to safely test and deploy the official patch in a controlled manner. This combination of immediate mitigation and automated deployment empowers providers to manage high-priority security changes rapidly and safely.

column3: Management of the CPE shall use a secure protocol (e.g. TLS 1.2 or newer).

Furthermore, the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall can be used to ensure that only specified, secure management systems can access the management interfaces of the vCPE workloads.

column3: By default, all unsolicited incoming connections towards the customer's network shall be blocked by the CPE.

column3: Where network or user data leaves a provider's control, the provider shall contractually require and verify that the data is properly protected as a consequence. This shall include assessing the third party supplier's controls to ensure provider data is only visible or accessible to appropriate employees and from appropriate locations.
column5: While contractual requirements are organizational responsibilities, VCF/TCP provides comprehensive technical controls to protect data when it leaves provider control and to verify third-party protection measures. For data in transit, VCF/TCP enforces encryption using TLS 1.2 or 1.3 for all management interfaces and supports IPsec VPN for secure site-to-site connectivity. VMware vDefend Gateway Firewall can enforce encryption requirements at network boundaries, blocking unencrypted data transfers. vSAN encryption and vSphere VM Encryption protect data at rest, ensuring sensitive information remains encrypted even when transferred to third-party storage systems. VCF Operations for Logs enables providers to ingest and correlate audit logs from third-party environments, verifying that access controls are properly enforced and monitoring for unauthorized data access. Data loss prevention capabilities can be integrated through VMware vDefend's network inspection engine, which can identify and block sensitive data patterns in outbound traffic. VCF/TCP's comprehensive audit framework logs all data export operations, including user identity, data classification, destination, and transfer method, providing evidence for compliance verification. Network flow monitoring through VCF Operations for Networks visualizes all data paths, enabling providers to validate that data only reaches authorized third-party systems.

column3: When sharing user or network data, providers and suppliers shall use an encrypted and authenticated channel.

Data can be shared with suppliers from a VM that uses VM Encryption (for data-at-rest) and vDefend firewall rules can mandate that all egress traffic must use an encrypted protocol (e.g., HTTPS, SFTP) over a secure NSX IPsec VPN tunnel, creating an authenticated and encrypted channel.

column3: Providers shall not allow routine, direct access to network equipment by third party administrators. Access shall be via mediation points owned and operated by the provider.
column5: VCF/TCP enables providers to enforce this control by hosting the required "mediation points" (such as a secure jump box) as virtual machines on the VCF/TCP. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall (DFW) is then used to create a "default-deny" policy for the management plane. A specific, high-priority firewall rule is created to only allow management traffic (e.g., SSH, HTTPS) from the IP address of that provider-owned mediation point to the management interfaces of the network equipment (vCenter, VCF Operations, NSX Manager). This firewall acts as the "security enforcing function" at the logical edge of the provider's network. It can be configured with strict ingress firewall policies to ensure that only authorized traffic from the third-party administrator's network is permitted. Furthermore, the gateway can serve as the termination point for a secure IPsec VPN tunnel from the third party, ensuring all access is authenticated and encrypted before it reaches the provider network.

column5:
VCF/TCP provides integrated lifecycle management tools for infrastructure updates and patch deployment with zero-downtime maintenance capabilities through the Distributed Resource Scheduler (DRS). VCF includes built-in alerts for security vulnerabilities and available updates. Broadcom maintains a security advisory system through web publications and email notifications to inform customers of security updates and patches. VCF/TCP supports staged rollouts, rollback capabilities, and integration with change management processes. Live Patching capabilities update and restart discrete components without requiring host evacuation.

VCF Operations orchestration provides centralized lifecycle management for the entire stack. Pre-update validation performs health checks and compatibility verification before updates. Update bundle management enables download, staging, and repository management for offline environments. Component interdependency management ensures orchestrated updates that respect dependencies between platform components.

vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) with Hardware Support Manager (HSM) plugins enables vendor-specific firmware and driver management. VCF/TCP supports Ensure Accessibility maintenance mode for vSAN storage clusters. This uses durability components to maintain data availability during updates. VMware Live Site Recovery supports N-1 version compatibility between sites for offline deployments. This enables phased upgrades across protected and recovery sites. Kubernetes workload lifecycle management includes automated updates for vSphere Kubernetes releases with support for rolling updates to maintain application availability.

Platform uses Configuration Profiles, Host Profiles, and Image-Based Lifecycle Management to periodically assess the configuration of hosts. It alerts if drift is detected and offers automated remediation. Security and operations teams can use interfaces, command-line interface (CLI) tools, and APIs to automate security posture assessment and remediation workflows. Teams can also integrate third-party monitoring, analysis, and Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools.

VCF Operations includes rule-based and machine learning-based analytics for proactive threat detection and anomaly identification. VCF/TCP tracks configuration drift across all infrastructure components. Administrators can trace configuration changes back to specific users and timestamps. This configuration management capability complements the Audit Events framework by providing detailed change tracking for compliance reporting and security investigations.

column3: Providers shall ensure their equipment is in a secure-by-default configuration, based on the principle that only required services are made available.
column5: VCF/TCP components are shipped with a secure-by-default configuration that aligns with the VMware Security Configuration Guide. This configuration disables unencrypted or unnecessary management protocols. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall enforces a "default-deny" policy, ensuring that no communication is permitted unless explicitly allowed. This principle of least privilege ensures only required services are accessible on the VCF/TCP's management components and between workloads.

column5: VCF/TCP provides integrated lifecycle management tools for infrastructure updates through VCF Operations and vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM). These tools automate patch deployment with zero-downtime maintenance capabilities. For security updates, VMware vDefend's "virtual patching" capability serves as a critical compensating control. By applying IDS/IPS signatures, it can block network-level exploits for a known vulnerability before the patch is deployed, mitigating risk and allowing providers to schedule the full update in an appropriate and timely manner.

column3: Providers shall deploy all security related patches and patches with a security element in a way that is proportionate to the risk of security compromise that the patch is intended to address (see Table 2). Should this not be possible, patches shall be deployed as soon as practicable and effective alternative mitigations put in place until the relevant patch has been deployed. Where a patch addresses an exposed, actively-exploited vulnerability, providers shall ensure that such patches are deployed as soon as can reasonably be achieved, and at most within 14 days of release.
column5: VCF/TCP's automated lifecycle management is what makes these rapid timelines achievable. Should an immediate deployment not be possible, VMware vDefend provides an "effective alternative mitigation" through its "virtual patching" capability. The vDefend Distributed IDS/IPS can apply a signature to block the network-level exploit, immediately shielding the vulnerable systems. This allows providers to meet the 14-day requirement by first mitigating the threat, and then using VCF Operations orchestration and vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) to deploy the permanent patch in a controlled, tested, and automated manner without requiring a large maintenance outage.

column3: Providers shall ensure that network equipment continues to meet the requirements in M8.04, M8.05, M8.06, M10.48 and M10.49 throughout its lifecycle including after an upgrade or patch.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: The provider shall verify that their third party network equipment suppliers have a vulnerability disclosure policy. This shall include, at a minimum, a public point of contact and details around timescales for communication.
column5:
Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

A top priority for Broadcom, in general terms, for its products and services offering, is to maintain the trust awarded to us by our customers. We recognize that unless our products meet the highest standards for security, customers will not be able to utilize them with confidence. To achieve this, the VMware Security Response Center (vSRC) maintains a program to identify, respond to, and address vulnerabilities. This publication documents our policies for addressing vulnerabilities in VMware Enterprise and Consumer Products (on-prem). It also describes under what circumstances we will issue a CVE identifier and VMware Security Advisory (VMSA), explains how to report a vulnerability in VMware-maintained code, defines terminology used in our publications and corrective actions, and documents our commitment to safe harbor practices. VMware External Vulnerability Response and Remediation Policy - https://www.broadcom.com/support/vmware-services/security-response

column3: Operational changes shall only be made according to a formal change process except under emergency or outage situations.
column5:
VCF/TCP implements granular role-based access control and additional authorization mechanisms to enforce access policies across infrastructure operations. Detailed logging monitors all changes. Integration with IT Service Management (ITSM) platforms enables change tracking and approval workflows. VCF/TCP maintains comprehensive audit trails for all configuration changes and supports rollback capabilities.

VCF Automation provides workflow processes that include change approval mechanisms for organizational change management requirements. 

vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) provides centralized lifecycle management for ESX hosts, drivers, firmware, and add-on software. vLCM uses desired state configuration to maintain consistency across infrastructure components and automatically detects and remediates configuration drift. This ensures all hosts remain compliant with approved baselines while providing detailed change tracking and rollback capabilities.

Change management extends to Kubernetes environments through vSphere Namespaces. Resource limits, storage policies, and access permissions require appropriate approvals before modification. VCF/TCP tracks all changes to namespace configurations, container deployments, and Kubernetes cluster lifecycle operations through unified audit logging. VCF Operations provides configuration drift detection and alerts administrators when unauthorized changes occur. This enables rapid remediation and maintains compliance with change control policies.

Platform uses Configuration Profiles, Host Profiles, and Image-Based Lifecycle Management to periodically assess host configurations. It alerts when drift is detected and offers automated remediation.

column3: Any persistent credentials and secrets (e.g., for break glass access) shall be protected and not available to anyone except for the responsible person(s) in an emergency.
column5:
VCF/TCP addresses this by providing native tools for credential management and supporting integration with dedicated "break-glass" systems.

VCF/TCP integrates with third-party Privileged Access Management (PAM) solutions, which is the recommended approach for this control. This allows all persistent credentials to be "vaulted," where they are not available to any user during normal operations. In an emergency, a "responsible person" must authenticate to the PAM system (using VCF SSO and MFA) to "check out" the credential, with all activity being logged.

Natively, VCF Operations provides unified password management for all VCF/TCP components. This centralized console allows administrators to set and rotate unique, strong passwords for each individual ESX host and management appliance. Access to this VCF Operations console is secured by VCF SSO and Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), ensuring that only a minimal set of "responsible persons" have the permissions to manage these credentials.

column3: Central storage for persistent credentials shall be protected by hardware means. For example, on a physical host the drive could be encrypted with the use of a TPM. Where a virtual machine (VM) is used to provide a central storage service, that VM and the data included in it shall also be encrypted, use secure boot and be configured to ensure that it can only be booted within an appropriate environment. This is to ensure that data cannot be removed from the operational environment and accessed.
column5: VCF/TCP addresses this at both the physical host and virtual machine levels. Physical ESX hosts, when equipped with a Trusted Platform Module (TPM), store their configuration encryption keys in this hardware-backed secure storage. For virtual machines, a virtual Trusted Platform Module (vTPM) can be enabled. This allows the VM's guest operating system to use the same hardware-backed security principles for its own persistent credentials and full disk encryption (e.g., BitLocker), ensuring the data cannot be removed and accessed.

column3: Privileged users are only granted specific privileged accounts and associated permissions which are essential to their business role or function.
column5: This is a foundational security principle enforced by VCF/TCP's Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) model. VCF/TCP provides pre-defined roles, such as the CloudAdmin role, which grants administrators the privileges needed to manage the fabric without granting access to guest VM data. Providers can also create granular, custom roles within VCF SSO to ensure all accounts are granted the minimum set of permissions necessary for their role, fulfilling the principle of least privilege.

column3: Privileged access shall be temporary, time-bounded and based on a ticket associated with a specific purpose. Administrators shall not be able to grant themselves privileged access to the network.
column5: While the ticketing system is organizational, VCF/TCP provides the automation framework to enforce this requirement technically. This is a primary use case for VCF Automation, which can integrate with external ITSM platforms like ServiceNow. A provider can build a workflow where an approved ticket triggers VCF Automation to run a script that adds a user to a specific, privileged VCF SSO group. A corresponding workflow can be triggered when the ticket is closed, which automatically removes the user from that group, thereby revoking the privileged access and automating the entire "temporary, time-bounded" access and revocation process.

column3: While open, tickets shall be updated daily as a record of why privileged access granted to a user remains required, and shall be closed once privileged access is no longer required.
column5: While the ticketing and review process is an organizational implementation, VCF/TCP provides the necessary audit trail to support it. VCF Operations for Logs and the VCF Operations Audit Events framework capture a detailed, attributable log of all privileged user activity. This log data can be correlated against open tickets, providing the evidence required for an auditor or manager to verify that the privileged access is still required and is being used only for its stated purpose.

column3: Privileged access shall be automatically revoked once the ticket is closed.
column5: While the ticketing system is organizational, VCF/TCP provides the automation framework to enforce this requirement technically. This is a primary use case for VCF Automation, which can integrate with external ITSM platforms like ServiceNow. A provider can build a workflow where an approved ticket triggers VCF Automation to run a script that adds a user to a specific, privileged VCF SSO group. A corresponding workflow can be triggered when the ticket is closed, which automatically removes the user from that group, thereby revoking the privileged access and automating the entire "temporary, time-bounded" access and revocation process.

column3: Privileged user accounts are generated from a least privilege role template and modified as required. The permissions associated with this account shall not be copied from existing users.
column5: This is a foundational security principle enforced by VCF/TCP's Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) model. VCF/TCP provides pre-defined roles, such as the CloudAdmin role, which grants administrators the privileges needed to manage the fabric without granting access to guest VM data. Providers can also create granular, custom roles within VCF SSO to ensure all accounts are granted the minimum set of permissions necessary for their role, fulfilling the principle of least privilege.

column3: Given a business need, administrators can have multiple roles, each with its own account, provided the risk of doing so has been considered and accepted as part of the provider's risk management processes.
column5: This is an organizational risk management decision. VCF/TCP provides the technical framework to implement this policy by enforcing a strict separation of duties. Through VCF SSO and its Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) model, a single administrator can be provisioned with multiple, distinct accounts. Each account can be assigned a unique role with the minimum necessary permissions, such as a "CloudAdmin" account for fabric management and a separate, less-privileged account for daily monitoring, thereby technically enforcing the separation of roles.

column3: When an emergency occurs, security requirements may temporarily be suspended. Clean-up steps shall be performed after the emergency is resolved to ensure the suspension of these requirements has not compromised the network. Where an 'emergency' event occurs, this shall be recorded and audited, along with the reason and time period for which controls were suspended.
column5: While the emergency process is organizational, VCF/TCP provides the complete, centralized audit trail required to perform the "clean-up steps" and verify all actions taken. The VCF Operations Audit Events framework and VCF Operations for Logs capture all privileged logins and configuration changes, attributed to a unique user. This allows auditors to review every action taken during the emergency, identify any temporary "suspensions," and confirm that all configurations were returned to a secure, compliant state.

column3: Break-glass privileged user accounts should be present for emergency access outside of change windows, but alerts shall be raised when these are used, the circumstances investigated, and all activity logs audited post emergency.
column5:
VCF/TCP directly addresses this requirement through its comprehensive logging and real-time alerting capabilities. When a break-glass account is used, such as the local vCenter account (e.g., administrator@vsphere.local) or the root account for direct ESX host access, VCF SSO logs the successful authentication event, capturing a specific event ID for this high-risk activity.

This log data is collected by VCF Operations for Logs, which can be configured with custom queries and alerting rules to actively monitor for these specific login event IDs and send notifications when they occur. In parallel, the native vCenter Server events and alarms framework can also be configured to generate an immediate, real-time alert based on these same login events, ensuring security teams are notified instantly.

For post-emergency investigation and audit, the VCF Operations Audit Events framework captures a detailed, attributable audit trail of all actions performed during the privileged session. This allows security teams to investigate the circumstances of the access, review all configuration modifications, and verify that all activity was appropriate for the emergency.

column3: Break-glass privileged user account credentials should be single-use and changed after use.
column5: While this is an organizational policy, VCF/TCP provides the exact tool to enforce it. The VCF Operations console's unified password management feature is the mechanism used to "change the password after use." After a break-glass account is used in an emergency, an administrator uses this centralized console to rotate and remediate the credential, ensuring a new, unique, strong password is set for each component (like an ESX host), thus rendering the "single-use" credential invalid.

column3: All privileged access activity undertaken during a management session shall be fully recorded.
column5:
VMware vSphere provides comprehensive tools to track system events and user actions for monitoring and security. Basic logs are viewable through the Tasks and Events tab in the vSphere Client. This helps track changes and troubleshoot issues. For detailed analysis, VCF Operations for Logs collects logs from vCenter Server and ESX hosts. It offers advanced dashboards and analytics for deeper insights.

The VCF Operations Audit Events framework captures VCF/TCP interactions including user logins and logouts, capability checks, and configuration modifications across vSphere, vSAN, and NSX resources. This framework enhances transparency, control, and accountability by registering each action as an event. It enables detection of suspicious access patterns and policy violations while providing user accountability through detailed activity tracking.

ESX hosts maintain local logging with configurable retention and rotation policies for forensic purposes. vCenter Server provides database retention policies with automated cleanup based on age or database size. API audit logging captures REST API calls, SDK usage, and PowerCLI commands with user attribution. Storage operation logging tracks vSAN operations, datastore actions, and storage policy changes. NSX-T maintains audit trails for all network configuration changes including firewall rules, segments, and routing modifications.

Platform allows configuration of syslog to forward logs to up to three syslog forwarding targets using various protocols. Log forwarding supports TLS encryption to ensure confidentiality in transit. VCF Operations for Logs provides centralized log retention policies configurable by log type, source, and compliance requirements. Certificate lifecycle events including generation, renewal, revocation, and expiration are logged for security tracking. Time synchronization audit captures NTP events and drift corrections for forensic accuracy.

vSphere High Availability (HA) maintains detailed logs of all failover operations, host isolation events, and admission control decisions for audit trail purposes. VMware Live Site Recovery maintains detailed logs of all recovery operations, protection group changes, and recovery plan executions.

Kubernetes audit logging captures all API calls to the vSphere Supervisor. This includes namespace operations, pod deployments, and role-based access control (RBAC) changes. It provides complete visibility into container platform activities. Authentication events are logged for all identity sources. This includes successful and failed login attempts, password changes, and permission modifications through vCenter Single Sign-On.

vDefend provides Layer 7 traffic statistics with detailed logging of packet counts, flow statistics, protocol breakdowns, and CPU usage across cores for forensic analysis. vDefend Intrusion Detection System/Intrusion Prevention System (IDS/IPS) event correlation enables advanced event generation from custom signatures with detailed metadata for security investigations. This includes signature severity levels and threat categories.

Platform maintains comprehensive audit trails for all configuration changes and supports rollback capabilities. Change management extends to Kubernetes environments through vSphere Namespaces. Resource limits, storage policies, and access permissions require appropriate approvals before modification. VCF tracks all changes to namespace configurations, container deployments, and Kubernetes cluster lifecycle operations through unified audit logging.

column3: A device that is not necessary to perform network management or support management operations shall not be able to logically access the management plane.
column5: This is enforced by the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall (DFW), which microsegments the management plane. A "default-deny" policy is applied to all components. Explicit, "allow" rules are then created only for necessary communication paths (e.g., VCF Operations to vCenter). Any device that is not part of this "allow" list is logically blocked from accessing the management plane by default.

column3: Privileged access to network equipment shall be via a centralised element manager or equivalent configuration deployment system. For example, privileged users shall not be provided with direct access to any management terminal, except where network connectivity is not available (e.g. break-glass situations).
column5: VCF/TCP's architecture enforces this model by default. Privileged users do not get direct access to individual network equipment (e.g., ESX hosts). Instead, all privileged access is mediated through "centralised element managers" like vCenter Server and the VCF Operations console. Authentication is centralized via VCF SSO (which supports MFA), and all actions are performed through these management platforms, eliminating the need for direct host access except in "break-glass" situations.

column3: It shall not be possible to directly communicate between managed elements over the management plane.
column5: VCF/TCP enforces this at a granular level using the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall (DFW). All management components (vCenter, ESX hosts, NSX Manager, VCF Operations) reside on the management network, and the DFW can apply stateful firewall policies to their virtual NICs. VCF/TCP is configured with a "default-deny" policy, and explicit rules only permit the necessary communication paths. This prevents unauthorized direct communication between managed elements, blocking lateral movement on the management plane.

column3: The management plane shall be segregated by third party supplier, and between access networks and core networks (e.g. by VLAN). This would not preclude the use of a single orchestration and management solution, provided it is compliant with measure M11.23.
column5: VCF/TCP's Workload Domain architecture enables this segregation. A provider can place third-party managed services into a dedicated, separate Workload Domain, isolating them from the primary management plane. Logical segregation between network tiers (like access and core, which run as workloads) and the management plane (the VCF Management Domain) is a core principle of the architecture. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall then enforces these logical boundaries with its distributed firewalling policies.

column3: The management plane shall be configured to ensure that only necessary connections are allowed. Specifically, element managers and other administrative functions shall only be able to communicate with the network equipment that they administer. Further, network equipment shall only be able to communicate with its administrative functions and its ability to establish a connection with these functions shall be limited.
column5: This is directly enforced by the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall (DFW), which microsegments the management plane. The DFW is configured with a "default-deny" policy, and explicit rules are created to only allow necessary connections (e.g., vCenter to ESX hosts, VCF Operations to vCenter). This ensures that "element managers" (like vCenter) can only communicate with the equipment they administer and blocks all other unnecessary communication.

column3: The function authorising privileged user access (e.g. the root authentication service) shall be within a trusted security domain (not the corporate network).
column5: This is a core architectural principle of VCF/TCP. The "function authorising privileged user access," which is VCF SSO, runs within the VCF Management Domain. This domain is architecturally isolated from all other workloads (e.g., in Workload Domains) and is intended to run on dedicated, secured hardware. It is protected by vDefend firewall rules, establishing it as the trusted, separate security domain for all platform authentication and authorization.

column3: Multi-factor authentication supporting and authorisation functions shall be treated as a network oversight function and shall be within a separate security domain to the corporate security domain.
column5: This is a core architectural principle of VCF/TCP. The "function authorising privileged user access," which is VCF SSO, runs within the VCF Management Domain. This domain is architecturally isolated from all other workloads (e.g., in Workload Domains) and is intended to run on dedicated, secured hardware. It is protected by vDefend firewall rules, establishing it as the trusted, separate security domain for all platform authentication and authorization.

column3: Testing procedures shall be established and utilised to verify that management networks enforce these controls.
column5: While establishing testing procedures is an organizational responsibility, VCF/TCP provides tools to verify these controls. VCF Operations for Networks can visualize network traffic flows on the management plane, allowing an auditor to see and confirm that the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall rules are active and that only the expected, necessary connections are permitted. This visual verification can be used as part of the formal testing procedures.

column3: The provider's wider network outside of the management plane shall be continuously scanned to detect and remediate unnecessary open management protocols, ports and services.
column5: VCF/TCP provides this capability through VCF Operations. The compliance engine within VCF Operations can continuously scan all hosts against a defined security baseline, such as the VMware Security Configuration Guide. These benchmarks include rules to detect unnecessary open management ports or services. If a host's configuration drifts and an unnecessary protocol is opened, VCF Operations will detect this and raise an alert, enabling rapid remediation.

column3: The management plane shall be segregated in such a way that a disruption to a segment shall not affect the entirety of the provider's UK network.
column5:
VCF/TCP's core architecture is designed to enable this segregation through the use of Workload Domains and multiple VCF instances. A provider would not run their entire UK network on a single management plane. Instead, they can deploy multiple, independent VCF instances (e.g., one for each major region) or, within a single VCF instance, create multiple Workload Domains.

Each Workload Domain functions as a separate management plane segment, deploying its own dedicated vCenter Server and NSX Manager cluster. This design provides the required segregation. A disruption to a single segment, such as a vCenter failure in one Workload Domain, is isolated to that domain and will not affect the management and operation of any other Workload Domain or the VCF Management Domain. This architectural separation ensures a disruption in one part of the management plane does not compromise the entirety of the provider's network.

column3: A PAW shall only have access to the internet to the extent it is needed to carry out changes to security critical functions, and such access shall be secured (e.g. via VPN).
column5: This is an organizational policy for Privileged Access Workstations (PAWs). VCF/TCP provides the secure infrastructure to host these PAWs as virtual machines. Using the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall, a provider can create granular, "default-deny" egress policies for the PAW, ensuring it can only access the internet via a specified VPN or secure gateway and that all other access is blocked.

column3: The PAW shall only have access to internal-only business systems (e.g. not corporate email).
column5: This is an organizational policy for Privileged Access Workstations (PAWs). When a PAW is hosted as a virtual machine on VCF/TCP, the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall is used to enforce this control. A "default-deny" policy is applied, with explicit "allow" rules created only for the PAW to access the VCF management plane. All other internal traffic, such as to corporate email systems, would be blocked.

column3: A PAW shall support secure boot, boot-attestation, data-at-rest encryption backed by a hardware root-of-trust.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: A PAW shall be kept patched and up-to-date with a supported OS throughout its lifetime.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: Security critical patches shall be applied to PAWs within 14 days. Should this not be possible, patches shall be deployed to PAWs as soon as practicable and robust alternative mitigations put in place until the relevant patch has been deployed.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: A PAW shall prevent the execution of unauthorised code such as binaries or macros within documents.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: A PAW shall use data-at-rest encryption.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: Health attestation of the PAW shall be used wherever possible, and particularly where the PAW is located outside the UK.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: All new deployments of equipment shall be administered via secure, encrypted and authenticated protocols. Insecure or proprietary security protocols shall be disabled.
column5: VCF/TCP enforces this requirement by default for all VCF/TCP components. Every management interface uses TLS 1.2 or 1.3 encryption for all administrative traffic. Authentication is centralized through VCF SSO with support for multi-factor authentication and federation to external identity providers. Legacy insecure protocols such as Telnet, SNMPv1/v2, and unencrypted HTTP are disabled by default. VCF/TCP's compliance checking capabilities continuously verify that only secure protocols remain enabled for administrative access.

column3: Where administrative access is not via secure channels, the risk this poses and the mitigation applied shall be justified, fully documented and reported at board level.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: Security protocols and algorithms shall not be proprietary whenever technically viable.
column5:
VCF/TCP fully adheres to this principle by exclusively using industry-standard, non-proprietary security protocols and algorithms. All cryptographic operations for VCF/TCP rely on FIPS 140-3 validated cryptographic modules, such as platform-provided OpenSSL libraries, ensuring a high level of security and compliance that has been independently verified.

For data-in-transit, VCF/TCP uses standardized cipher suites, with Transport Layer Security (TLS) 1.3 as the default for all management and internal communications and TLS 1.2 as a compatibility fallback. For data-at-rest, features like vSAN encryption use the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES), accelerated by standard AES-NI CPU instructions. Furthermore, all key management relies on the Key Management Interoperability Protocol (KMIP) 1.1, an open standard for communicating with Key Management Servers (KMS). By building on these open, internationally recognized standards, VCF/TCP avoids proprietary security protocols.

column3: Each network equipment shall have strong, unique credentials for every account.
column5: VCF/TCP does not use generic, "well-known" default passwords. The requirement to change passwords upon initialization is enforced as a mandatory step in the deployment process. When you deploy VCF/TCP or its components, you must either specify a strong, unique password for each component account or have the system auto-generate a complex, random password. No default credentials are left on the device after this initial setup. After deployment, these passwords can be centrally managed, rotated, and remediated via the VCF Operations console. Password policies, such as complexity, history, and timeouts, are enforced by VCF SSO or can be federated to an external identity provider.

column3: Incoming and outgoing signalling traffic shall be monitored.
column5: VCF/TCP provides comprehensive tools to monitor signalling traffic. VCF Operations for Networks provides deep visibility into network traffic flows, allowing operators to visualize, analyze, and baseline signalling patterns between workloads and across gateways. For deeper inspection, the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall provides Layer 7 application-aware firewalling and can log all accepted or dropped traffic. These logs, enriched with flow details, can be streamed in real time to VCF Operations for Logs or an external SIEM for continuous monitoring and analysis.

column3: Signalling records are sensitive data and shall be protected from misuse or extraction.
column5: VCF/TCP provides multiple layers of protection for sensitive signalling data. vSAN encryption with FIPS 140-2 validated cryptographic modules protects data at rest, including all signalling records stored on the VCF/TCP. VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall applies zero-trust network policies to prevent unauthorized access to signalling data stores. VCF Operations Audit Events framework logs all access to sensitive data repositories, creating a complete audit trail. For signalling workloads running on the VCF/TCP, vSphere VM Encryption can provide per-workload encryption with independent key management.

column3: Security analysis shall be performed on signalling traffic to find and address anomalous signalling and malicious signalling.
column5: VCF/TCP performs multi-layered security analysis. For malicious signalling, the vDefend Distributed Malware Prevention (DMP) engine provides agentless, host-level file scanning to detect and block malware on the workloads processing the signals. For network-level analysis, the vDefend Distributed IDS/IPS uses both signature-based detection for known threats and anomaly-based detection for zero-day threats. To find anomalous signalling, the vDefend Network Traffic Analysis (NTA) capability functions as an NDR solution, automatically building dynamic baselines of normal signalling behavior and flagging suspicious deviations, such as a workload communicating on an unexpected port or with a new external entity.

column3: Providers shall establish an effective means to alert each other to malicious signalling where there could be a connected security compromise.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: Detailed negative testing and fuzzing shall be performed for all interfaces that process data provided over an external signalling interface (this applies to all equipment that this measure applies to, including existing equipment). The provider shall test that the live configuration prevents malformed, inconsistent, unexpected, or abnormally high volumes of signalling messages from disrupting security critical functions.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: The virtualisation fabric shall be robustly locked-down, shall use the latest patch for the software version and shall be in support.
column5: VCF/TCP addresses this with a multi-layered approach. At the hardware level, the fabric is "robustly locked-down" using Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs) in the ESX hosts. The TPM enables Secure Boot, which performs code signing and verification of code integrity that cannot be disabled. This provides a hardware-rooted guarantee that the hosts are running a known-good, trusted hypervisor. At the software level, VCF Operations provides centralized lifecycle management to ensure the fabric is on the latest patch and uses compliance benchmarks to continuously monitor the infrastructure against the VMware Security Configuration Guide.

column3: It shall be possible to update the virtualisation fabric without negatively impacting the network functionality.
column5: VCF Operations provides a comprehensive set of tools for managing the lifecycle of both VCF management components and VCF core components. You can use VCF Operations to download and manage upgrade, patch, and install binaries. You can also manage ESX components and vSphere Lifecycle Manager images and deploy optional VCF management components.

column3: All interfaces on physical hosts shall be locked down to restrict access. The only incoming connection to the physical host shall be for management purposes or to support the virtualisation function. There shall be no outgoing connections except to support virtual workloads. Communication between physical hosts shall be inhibited other than as part of data flows between virtual workloads.
column5: VCF/TCP enforces this by default. VCF/TCP abstracts physical host interfaces using vSphere Distributed Switches (VDS) and assigns specific services, such as Management, vMotion, and vSAN, to dedicated VMkernel (vmk) ports. Access to these management interfaces is then locked down by the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall (DFW). The DFW applies "default-deny" policies to permit only necessary traffic and inhibits all unauthorized communication between physical hosts on the management plane, blocking any traffic not explicitly required for platform operation.
