column3: Controls shall be in place to ensure that only known physical hosts can be added to the virtualisation fabric.
column5: VCF ensures this through a combination of privileged access control and a mandatory manual verification process. Adding a new ESX host to the fabric is a privileged, auditable action that must be initiated from VCF Operations and vCenter. During this process, vCenter establishes a secure connection to the host and presents the host's SHA-256 certificate thumbprint to the administrator. The administrator is required to manually verify that this thumbprint matches the one on the host's console (DCUI). This human-in-the-loop verification step is the critical control that prevents spoofed or "unknown" hosts from being added to the trusted virtualisation fabric.

column3: Modification of databases and systems that define the operation of the network shall require sign off by two authorised persons.
column5: While the "two-person sign-off" is an organizational governance policy, VCF/TCP provides the technical framework to enforce it using VCF Automation. A provider can define high-risk operations (e.g., modifying a critical network database) as a VCF Automation workflow. This workflow can then be configured with a custom approval policy that requires sign-off from two separate authorized individuals or groups before the workflow is permitted to execute the change, thus technically enforcing the business rule.

column3: As part of the virtualisation fabric, physically separate ports shall be used to segregate internal interface and external interface network traffic.
column5: VCF/TCP's architecture uses vSphere Distributed Switches (VDS) and multiple physical NICs (pNICs) to enforce this. The VCF Management Domain, for example, requires separate pNICs for management and vMotion traffic. Workload Domains can be configured with dedicated pNICs for internal/backend traffic (like vSAN or vMotion) and separate pNICs for external-facing workload traffic, ensuring physical port-level segregation.

column3: The virtualisation fabric shall be configured to limit the exposure of virtual workloads (e.g. disable virtual span ports by default).
column5: The VCF fabric is secure by default. Features that could expose workload traffic, such as virtual SPAN ports (port mirroring), are disabled by default and require privileged access to enable. More importantly, the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall (DFW) operates on a "default-deny" principle, meaning no traffic is allowed between workloads unless an explicit "allow" rule is created, minimizing exposure.

column3: The virtualisation fabric shall be configured to prevent use of hard-coded MAC addresses by default (e.g. by individual VNFs).
column5: VCF/TCP prevents this at two levels. First, vCenter Server automatically generates and assigns a unique MAC address to each virtual NIC (vNIC) from a managed pool, avoiding manual hard-coding. Second, NSX SpoofGuard can be enabled to bind a workload's IP address to its authorized MAC address. This prevents a workload from illegitimately changing its MAC address, as any traffic not matching the vCenter-assigned MAC will be blocked.

column3: Where providers cannot guarantee the security of the physical environment (e.g. within the exposed edge, or within a shared data centre/exchange), the virtualisation fabric shall be configured to encrypt data at rest (no data is written to the host's storage unencrypted and data is encrypted when the host is powered off).
column5: VCF/TCP provides this capability through vSAN Data-at-Rest Encryption. This feature encrypts all data at the storage layer before it is written to disk, using the industry-standard AES-256 cipher. Encryption keys are managed by an external KMIP-compatible Key Management Server (KMS) or the vSphere Native Key Provider, ensuring data on the host's storage is unreadable if the host is powered off or stolen.

column3: Where there is risk of exposure during transmission, the virtualisation fabric shall be configured to securely encrypt data in transit. Examples and guidance on the use of encryption can be found on the NCSC website.
column5: VCF/TCP provides multiple features to encrypt data in transit. Encrypted vSphere vMotion secures the memory and disk data of a VM as it is migrated between hosts, preventing interception. For storage traffic, vSAN Data-in-Transit (DIT) encryption can be enabled to secure all vSAN RDT traffic between hosts in a cluster, protecting against packet sniffing on the storage network.

column3: All physical hosts shall be placed into a host security 'pool'. Pools may be defined based on the environment within which that host resides, the type of host, resilience and diversity, purpose etc.
column5:
VCF/TCP infrastructure is organized into Resource Pools, Regions and Zones. The infrastructure does not assume any trust between the services that are running on the infrastructure. This trust model is referred to as a zero-trust security model. A zero-trust security model means that no devices or users are trusted by default, whether they are inside or outside of the network.

In addition, VCF/TCP integrates with VMware vDefend to implement zero-trust lateral security. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall is a software-defined, distributed firewall that provides granular, context-based enforcement for VCF workloads. This ensures that workloads are protected even within the VCF infrastructure, preventing lateral movement of threats. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall is crucial for zero-trust as it isolates workloads and limits their communication.

column3: Virtual workloads shall be authorised, tagged with a specific trust domain, and signed prior to use. The specific trust domain shall be based on the risks associated with the workload.
column5: VCF/TCP addresses this requirement through multiple capabilities. Workloads are "authorized" and "tagged" using VCF/TCP's resource hierarchy (Organizations, Projects) and network isolation (VPCs). To address the "signed" requirement for virtual machine workloads, VCF/TCP supports vSphere Secure Boot, which ensures that the guest OS bootloader and drivers are cryptographically signed. For containerized workloads, VCF/TCP integrates a container registry that can be configured to scan images and enforce policies, ensuring only trusted and signed container images are deployed.

column3: There shall be separation between trust domains. This separation may be enforced by the virtualisation fabric, provided virtualisation cut-throughs are not used.
column5:
By default, VPCs are protected at the network level by a VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall and all platform resources are protected at the API level by default IAM configurations. The infrastructure does not assume any trust between the services that are running on the infrastructure.
This trust model is referred to as a zero-trust security model. A zero-trust security model means that no devices or users are trusted by default, whether they are inside or outside of the network.

The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall and IAM features are highly configurable according to customer needs.

The VMware vDefend Distributed feature provides a service perimeter access with granular control over who can access resource APIs based on location, IP address and device. This is incremental to IAM protection.

Within VMware vDefend platform also supports a Zero-Trust security architecture with Micro-segmentation
This will reduce the attack surface and isolate applications with contextual segmentation policies that restrict threat lateral movement.

column3: Host pools shall be tagged with trust domains they can execute. This will be based on risk and ensure that sensitive functions are not executed alongside vulnerable functions, or in physically exposed locations. The virtualisation fabric shall verify that the virtual workload is signed and complies with policy prior to use, including that the virtual workload's trust domain is permitted to execute within the host's pool.
column5: In VCF/TCP, organization policies can be used to limit the locations in which resources within an Org, Folder, or Project across Regions and Zones can be deployed. For more granular control over workload placement (VMs and Containers) and to create "host pools" based on trust, customers can use the tenancy model to get exclusive access to one or more physical compute servers. These can be managed in groups, with control over affinity and anti-affinity for particular workloads. Regarding "signing" of virtual workloads, Binary Authorization can be used to ensure only containers signed by a trusted authority can be deployed within vSphere Kubernetes Service (VKS) or VMware Tanzu Kubernetes Grid (TKG). For Virtual Machines, VCF/TCP supports vSphere Secure Boot, which verifies that the guest OS bootloader and drivers are cryptographically signed, ensuring the workload itself is in a known-good state.

column3: A physical host shall not be able to impact hosts in other host pools. This includes, but is not limited to, spoofing VLAN/VXLANs of virtual networks.
column5: VCF/TCP's virtual networking layer is designed to prevent this. The vSphere Distributed Switch (VDS) and NSX logical switches manage all L2 traffic. A VM cannot tag its own traffic with an arbitrary VLAN or VXLAN ID; this tagging is applied by the switch port the VM is connected to. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall then enforces policy at L4-L7, ensuring that even if L2 was compromised, the traffic would be blocked, preventing a host from impacting other network segments.

column3: Containers shall not be used to implement separation between trust domains. To implement separation between trust domains, providers shall use Type-1 hypervisors (without cut-throughs) or discrete physical hardware.
column5: VCF/TCP's architecture fully complies with this requirement. VCF/TCP runs containerized workloads (e.g., Kubernetes pods via vSphere with Tanzu) on top of the ESX Type-1 hypervisor. In this model, the hypervisor (ESX) provides the fundamental, hardware-enforced security boundary between all workloads, including between different containers. This robust isolation is then further enforced by the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall, ensuring containers are not used as the primary boundary between trust domains.

column3: Containerised hosts shall only support a single trust domain.
column5: This is an architectural control enabled by VCF. To meet this, a provider would create a dedicated Workload Domain (a separate vCenter and cluster of ESX hosts) specifically for containerized workloads of a single trust domain. This ensures that container hosts are physically segregated from hosts running other trust domains (e.g., the management domain or a VM-based workload domain), preventing co-tenancy issues.

column3: The control and orchestration functions for virtualisation are network oversight functions and shall reside in a trusted physical and logical location.
column5: VCF/TCP's architecture enforces this through the VCF Management Domain. All control and orchestration functions (like vCenter, NSX Manager, and VCF Operations) are deployed into this dedicated, secured cluster. This Management Domain is logically isolated by vDefend firewall rules and is intended to run on physically separate hardware from all other workloads, establishing it as the trusted physical and logical location for platform administration.

column3: The administration network of the virtualisation fabric is a management plane and shall be protected as such.
column5: VCF/TCP's administration network (i.e., the management VLAN/subnet) is the management plane. It is protected by default through network architecture and firewalling. vDefend policies are used to ensure that only designated administrative systems (like jump boxes) can access the management interfaces of components (vCenter, ESX, etc.) on this network, and that these components can only communicate with each other as necessary.

column3: Privileged access to the virtualisation fabric shall only be available over authenticated and encrypted channels.
column5: VCF/TCP enforces this for all privileged access to the virtualization fabric. All management interfaces, including the vCenter Client, VCF Operations console, and all component APIs, use Transport Layer Security (TLS 1.3/1.2) by default. Authentication is centralized via VCF SSO (which can be MFA-enabled) and direct, unencrypted access to ESX hosts is disabled and eliminated in favor of this centralized, encrypted, and authenticated model.

column3: Functions that support the administration and security of the virtualisation fabric shall not be run on the fabric it is administering.
column5: This is a core architectural principle of VCF/TCP. The administrative and security functions (vCenter, NSX Manager, VCF Operations) are deployed into a dedicated VCF Management Domain. The workloads this fabric administers (e.g., the provider's applications) are run in separate Workload Domains. This ensures a "separation of concerns" where the management components are not co-located with the workloads they manage.

column3: Functions that support the administration and security of the virtualisation fabric are network oversight functions and shall reside in a trusted physical and logical location.
column5: VCF/TCP's architecture enforces this through the VCF Management Domain. All control and orchestration functions (like vCenter, NSX Manager, and VCF Operations) are deployed into this dedicated, secured cluster. This Management Domain is logically isolated by vDefend firewall rules and is intended to run on physically separate hardware from all other workloads, establishing it as the trusted physical and logical location for platform administration.

column3: The number of privileged accounts for the virtualisation fabric shall be constrained to the minimum necessary to meet the provider's needs.
column5: This is enforced using role-based access control (RBAC) in vCenter and other components. VCF provides pre-defined roles, such as the CloudAdmin role, which grants necessary administrative capabilities without providing full, platform-level "root" access (e.g., access to the underlying ESX hosts). Providers can also create custom roles with the minimum necessary permissions to meet business needs, adhering to the principle of least privilege.

column3: Virtualisation fabric administrator accounts shall not have any privileged rights to other services within the provider, or vice-versa.
column5: This separation of duties is enforced by VCF/TCP's RBAC model. A fabric administrator (e.g., a member of the CloudAdmin group) has no default permissions on other services, such as the workloads (VMs/containers) running on the fabric. Conversely, a workload administrator (e.g., a vSphere Namespace Owner) has no privileged rights to the underlying fabric (ESX, vCenter). Permissions are non-transferable and must be explicitly granted for each distinct service.

column3: Virtualisation fabric administrator accounts shall only be provided with the privileges and accesses required to carry out their role.
column5: This is a foundational security principle enforced by VCF/TCP's Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) model. VCF/TCP provides pre-defined roles, such as the CloudAdmin role, which grants administrators the privileges needed to manage the fabric (e.g., clusters, storage) without granting access to guest VM consoles or workload data. This separation of duties is explicit. Providers can also create granular, custom roles within VCF SSO to ensure all accounts, including fabric administrators, are granted the minimum set of permissions necessary for their role, fulfilling the principle of least privilege.

column3: Virtualisation fabric administrator accounts shall not have access to the provider's workloads running within the virtualised environment.
column5: This is a foundational security principle enforced by VCF/TCP's Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) model. VCF/TCP provides pre-defined roles, such as the CloudAdmin role, which grants administrators the privileges needed to manage the fabric (e.g., clusters, storage) without granting access to guest VM consoles or workload data. This separation of duties is explicit. Providers can also create granular, custom roles within VCF SSO to ensure all accounts, including fabric administrators, are granted the minimum set of permissions necessary for their role, fulfilling the principle of least privilege.

column3: Network oversight functions shall not share trust domains or host pools with workloads that are not network oversight functions.
column5: This is a customer design choice. As noted above,  platform enables physical segregation of hosts at the Region, Zone and Node level as well as logical segregation via Projects, Orgs and VPCs, with a range of related controls such as IAM, VMware vDefend and VPC Service Controls.

column3: Containers shall not be used to enforce separation between different network oversight functions and between network oversight functions and other functions.
column5: VCF/TCP's architecture fully complies with this requirement. VCF/TCP runs containerized workloads (e.g., Kubernetes pods via vSphere with Tanzu) on top of the ESX Type-1 hypervisor. In this model, the hypervisor (ESX) provides the fundamental, hardware-enforced security boundary between all workloads, including between different containers. This robust isolation is then further enforced by the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall, ensuring containers are not used as the primary boundary between trust domains.

column3: Once equipment reaches the vendor's end-of-life date, providers shall only continue to use the equipment if the following conditions are met: a) the equipment's configuration is rarely modified, and modifications are reviewed; b) either the addressable interfaces of the unsupported equipment are monitored and use of those interfaces can be explained, or there is no realistic possibility that exploitation of all unsupported equipment would have an impact on the network; and c) the network exposure (attack surface) of the unsupported equipment is minimal (e.g. some transport equipment).
column5:
VCF/TCP provides integrated lifecycle management tools for infrastructure updates and patch deployment with zero-downtime maintenance capabilities through the Distributed Resource Scheduler (DRS). VCF includes built-in alerts for security vulnerabilities and available updates. Broadcom maintains a security advisory system through web publications and email notifications to inform customers of security updates and patches. VCF/TCP supports staged rollouts, rollback capabilities, and integration with change management processes. Live Patching capabilities update and restart discrete components without requiring host evacuation.

VCF Operations orchestration provides centralized lifecycle management for the entire stack. Pre-update validation performs health checks and compatibility verification before updates. Update bundle management enables download, staging, and repository management for offline environments. Component interdependency management ensures orchestrated updates that respect dependencies between platform components.

vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) with Hardware Support Manager (HSM) plugins enables vendor-specific firmware and driver management. VCF/TCP supports Ensure Accessibility maintenance mode for vSAN storage clusters. This uses durability components to maintain data availability during updates. VMware Live Site Recovery supports N-1 version compatibility between sites for offline deployments. This enables phased upgrades across protected and recovery sites. Kubernetes workload lifecycle management includes automated updates for vSphere Kubernetes releases with support for rolling updates to maintain application availability.

Platform uses Configuration Profiles, Host Profiles, and Image-Based Lifecycle Management to periodically assess the configuration of hosts. It alerts if drift is detected and offers automated remediation. Security and operations teams can use interfaces, command-line interface (CLI) tools, and APIs to automate security posture assessment and remediation workflows. Teams can also integrate third-party monitoring, analysis, and Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools.

VCF Operations includes rule-based and machine learning-based analytics for proactive threat detection and anomaly identification. VCF/TCP tracks configuration drift across all infrastructure components. Administrators can trace configuration changes back to specific users and timestamps. This configuration management capability complements the Audit Events framework by providing detailed change tracking for compliance reporting and security investigations.

column3: The provider shall block and record any SIM OTA messages sent to their own SIMs, except where these are sent from allowed sources.
column5: The platform provides the network security controls necessary to implement blocking and logging requirements. VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall can apply granular filtering policies to SIM OTA traffic, blocking messages based on source address, protocol characteristics, or message signatures. NSX Gateway Firewall enforces perimeter controls for external OTA message sources. All blocked attempts are logged through the VMware vDefend logging framework, which captures source address, destination, timestamp, and block reason. These logs integrate with VCF Operations for Logs for centralized analysis and compliance reporting. Allowed OTA sources can be whitelisted through firewall rules, ensuring only authorized provisioning systems can send SIM management messages. The platform's zero-trust architecture ensures that even internal OTA message sources must be explicitly permitted rather than implicitly trusted.

column3: Network oversight functions shall be robustly locked-down, in support and patched within such period as is proportionate to the risk of security compromise that the patch is intended to address (see Table 2). Should this not be possible, patches shall be deployed on network oversight functions as soon as practicable and robust alternative mitigations put in place until the relevant patch has been deployed.
column5: VCF/TCP provides a multi-layered solution to ensure network oversight functions are robustly locked-down. VCF Operations and vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) provide centralized, automated lifecycle management to ensure components are patched proportionately to the risk. As an "effective alternative mitigation" for high-risk, zero-day exploits, VMware vDefend's "virtual patching" capability can apply IDS/IPS signatures to block network-level attacks before the patch is deployed. This is combined with VCF Operations compliance scanning to detect misconfigurations and VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall rules to ensure the management plane is locked-down and accessible only from authorized workstations.

column3: Any service that supports or contains network oversight functions shall be rebuilt from an up-to-date known-good software state every 24 months. This includes the operating system and application software. This can be performed in line with a system upgrade.
column5: VCF/TCP directly supports the 24-month rebuild requirement through its integrated lifecycle management capabilities. VCF Operations maintains versioned software bundles that represent known-good baseline configurations for all VCF/TCP components. These bundles include ESX hypervisor images, management component versions, and validated hardware compatibility. Providers can use vSphere Lifecycle Manager to maintain gold master images for network oversight workloads, ensuring rapid deployment from verified baseline states. VCF/TCP's workload domain architecture enables blue-green deployment strategies where new domains are built from current known-good baselines while existing services continue operating. Once validated, traffic can be migrated to the rebuilt domain with minimal disruption. For stateful services, vSphere vMotion and NSX allows migration of running workloads between infrastructure without downtime. VCF Operations tracks deployment dates and configuration baselines for all components, enabling providers to identify systems approaching the 24-month rebuild threshold. VCF/TCP's compliance checking capabilities can validate that rebuilt systems match approved baseline configurations before they enter production. Automated deployment through VCF Operations ensures consistency and reduces the risk of configuration drift during rebuild operations. This combination of baseline management, automated deployment, and migration capabilities enables providers to maintain the 24-month rebuild cadence while minimizing service impact.

column3: Any workstations or functions (e.g. jump boxes) through which it is possible to make administrative changes to network oversight functions shall be rebuilt from an up-to-date known-good software state on a yearly-basis. This applies to the workstation or function's operating systems and above.
column5: While the annual rebuild of these workstations is an organizational process, VCF/TCP's architecture directly enables and facilitates this requirement. First, VCF provides the necessary client-side administrative tools (such as the vSphere Client, PowerCLI, and the NSX UI) from a "known-good software state," as they are subject to the same rigorous Secure Development Lifecycle (SDL) practices as the core platform. This gives you a trusted source for the applications you install on your rebuilt workstations. Second, VCF/TCP's API-first design and comprehensive CLIs (like PowerCLI) enable you to manage your infrastructure as code, which promotes a "stateless" administration model. This architecture makes the annual rebuild practical by allowing you to store automation scripts externally; the workstation becomes "disposable" and can be easily redeployed from a golden image without complex reconfiguration. Finally, when this rebuilt "known-good" workstation connects, VCF enforces secure, encrypted, and authenticated channels (such as TLS 1.2+ and centralized, MFA-capable vCenter Single Sign-On) to ensure the integrity of the entire administrative session.

column3: Network oversight functions shall run on trusted platforms.
column5: VCF/TCP meets this by ensuring the underlying virtualization fabric is a trusted platform. This trust is established at the hardware level using Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs) in the ESX hosts. The TPM enables Secure Boot, which performs code signing and continuous verification of code integrity that cannot be disabled. Because the network oversight functions (like vCenter and NSX Manager) run as virtual machines on top of this cryptographically verified, trusted fabric, their integrity is protected from boot-level and hypervisor-level malware.

column3: Where providers cannot guarantee the security of the physical environment (e.g. within the exposed edge, or within a shared data centre/exchange) network oversight functions shall not be deployed.
column5: This is an organizational policy that is directly enforced by VCF/TCP's core architecture. All network oversight functions (such as vCenter Server and NSX Manager) are deployed into the dedicated VCF Management Domain. This domain is intended to run on a cluster of hosts in a physically secure, trusted location (e.g., a core data center), separate from any "exposed edge" or untrusted environments, thereby ensuring these critical functions are not deployed in high-risk physical locations.

column3: Network oversight functions shall only be managed by a minimal set of trusted privileged users.
column5: VCF/TCP enforces this using centralized authentication via VCF SSO and granular role-based access control (RBAC). Access to network oversight functions (like NSX Manager and vCenter) is restricted to specific, named user accounts. VCF/TCP provides roles like the CloudAdmin role to grant necessary administrative access while restricting the most sensitive, platform-level operations, ensuring a minimal set of trusted users can manage these functions.

column3: The management functions (e.g. jump box) used to manage network oversight functions shall only be accessible from designated PAWs.
column5: This is enforced at the network layer using the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall. Providers can create firewall rules for the management interfaces of network oversight functions (like NSX Manager or VCF Operations) that explicitly "allow" access only from a designated IP set or group representing the privileged access workstations (PAWs). All other access from any other source would be blocked by the default-deny policy.

column3: Dedicated management functions shall be used to manage network oversight functions.
column5: VCF/TCP's architecture enforces this by default. VCF/TCP's management functions (vCenter, NSX Manager, VCF Operations) are deployed as a dedicated, self-contained unit within the VCF Management Domain. This domain is architecturally separate from the Workload Domains that run provider services, ensuring that dedicated functions are used to manage the network.

column3: The management plane used to manage network oversight functions shall be isolated from other internal and external networks, including the management plane used by other equipment.
column5:
Customers can use vDefend which provides automated threat detection and containment through integrated Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS), network sandboxing, traffic analysis, and network detection and response features. When threats are detected, vDefend can automatically initiate forensic snapshots, network isolation, workload suspension, or power state changes. Quarantine policies enable automated virtual machine (VM) isolation based on security events, maintaining network separation while preserving forensic access for investigation. VMware Live Recovery enables automated workload recovery from protected states for incident remediation. This includes point-in-time recovery and rapid failback capabilities.

Platform extends automated response to containerized workloads. vDefend provides microsegmentation and security policies for Kubernetes pods and services. Network isolation can be automatically enforced at the namespace level to prevent lateral movement between compromised containers. vDefend Layer 7 Deep Packet Inspection enables automated Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) based traffic inspection and policy enforcement. Behavior-based detection automatically identifies anomalous activities beyond traditional signature-based approaches.

vSphere Distributed Resource Scheduler (DRS) provides automated workload balancing across hosts based on resource utilization. DRS continuously monitors CPU and memory usage, automatically migrating VMs to optimize performance and maintain balanced clusters. Configurable automation levels range from manual recommendations to fully automated operations, with affinity and anti-affinity rules ensuring business and technical requirements are met. Predictive DRS integrates with vRealize Operations metrics to proactively migrate workloads before resource contention occurs, preventing performance degradation through machine learning-based forecasting.

vSphere High Availability (HA) provides automated failover with admission control policies. These policies ensure sufficient resources remain available for VM restart after host failures. VCF supports multiple admission control policies including cluster resource percentage, slot policy, and dedicated failover hosts. Proactive HA integrates with hardware vendor monitoring to detect degraded components and evacuate VMs before failures occur. This includes automated responses to power supply, fan, storage, memory, and network component issues.

vSphere Fault Tolerance (FT) delivers automated zero-downtime protection for critical VMs through synchronous replication. FT maintains identical secondary VMs on separate hosts, providing instantaneous failover without data loss or service interruption. This automated protection operates transparently to applications and users, ensuring continuous availability for mission-critical workloads.

vCenter Server alarms enable automated actions triggered by specific infrastructure conditions. These automated responses include script execution, Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) traps, email notifications, and API calls. Administrators can configure multi-level triggers with escalation paths, ensuring appropriate automated responses based on severity and duration of conditions.

column3: All management accesses to network oversight functions shall be pre-authorised by a limited set of people who have been assigned with an appropriate role.
column5: This is an organizational process that VCF/TCP's RBAC model directly enables. "Pre-authorisation" is implemented by assigning privileged roles (like CloudAdmin) in VCF SSO to a limited, named set of people. Any user not in this group has no access. For temporary access, a provider would follow their organizational change management process to have an authorized administrator temporarily add a user to the appropriate group, with the action itself being fully logged.

column3: Changes to network oversight functions shall be monitored in real-time (e.g. Syslog).
column5:
VMware vSphere provides comprehensive tools to track system events and user actions for monitoring and security. Basic logs are viewable through the Tasks and Events tab in the vSphere Client. This helps track changes and troubleshoot issues. For detailed analysis, VCF Operations for Logs collects logs from vCenter Server and ESX hosts. It offers advanced dashboards and analytics for deeper insights.

The VCF Operations Audit Events framework captures VCF/TCP interactions including user logins and logouts, capability checks, and configuration modifications across vSphere, vSAN, and NSX resources. This framework enhances transparency, control, and accountability by registering each action as an event. It enables detection of suspicious access patterns and policy violations while providing user accountability through detailed activity tracking.

ESX hosts maintain local logging with configurable retention and rotation policies for forensic purposes. vCenter Server provides database retention policies with automated cleanup based on age or database size. API audit logging captures REST API calls, SDK usage, and PowerCLI commands with user attribution. Storage operation logging tracks vSAN operations, datastore actions, and storage policy changes. NSX maintains detailed audit trails for all network configuration changes including firewall rules, segments, and routing modifications.

Platform allows configuration of syslog to forward logs to up to three syslog forwarding targets using various protocols. Log forwarding supports TLS encryption to ensure confidentiality in transit. This same centralized logging approach can be extended to Privileged Access Workstations (PAWs) and other critical workloads. By forwarding guest OS audit logs from the PAW VMs to VCF Operations for Logs, providers can monitor for critical changes to the PAWs themselves, correlating those changes with administrative actions on the network oversight functions.

VCF Operations for Logs provides centralized log retention policies configurable by log type, source, and compliance requirements. Certificate lifecycle events including generation, renewal, revocation, and expiration are logged for security tracking. Time synchronization audit captures NTP events and drift corrections for forensic accuracy. vSphere High Availability (HA) maintains detailed logs of all failover operations, host isolation events, and admission control decisions for audit trail purposes. VMware Live Site Recovery maintains detailed logs of all recovery operations, protection group changes, and recovery plan executions.

Kubernetes audit logging captures all API calls to the vSphere Supervisor. This includes namespace operations, pod deployments, and role-based access control (RBAC) changes. It provides complete visibility into container platform activities.

Authentication events are logged for all identity sources. This includes successful and failed login attempts, password changes, and permission modifications through VCF SSO.

vDefend provides Layer 7 traffic statistics with detailed logging of packet counts, flow statistics, protocol breakdowns, and CPU usage across cores for forensic analysis. vDefend Intrusion Detection System/Intrusion Prevention System (IDS/IPS) event correlation enables advanced event generation from custom signatures with detailed metadata for security investigations. This includes signature severity levels and threat categories.

Platform maintains comprehensive audit trails for all configuration changes and supports rollback capabilities. Change management extends to Kubernetes environments through vSphere Namesces. Resource limits, storage policies, and access permissions require appropriate approvals before modification. VCF tracks all changes to namespace configurations, container deployments, and Kubernetes cluster lifecycle operations through unified audit logging.

column3: The designated PAWs, dedicated management functions and the network oversight functions themselves shall be monitored for signs of exploitation.
column5: VCF/TCP provides multi-layered monitoring to detect signs of exploitation. At the network level, the vDefend Distributed IDS/IPS and Network Traffic Analysis (NTA) capabilities detect exploits and anomalous behavior. Security analysts can then use VCF Operations for Networks to visualize these anomalous traffic flows in rich detail and understand their full application context. At the host level, vDefend Distributed Malware Prevention (DMP) provides agentless file scanning to detect and quarantine malware. All of these security events are correlated with platform logs in VCF Operations for Logs and privileged user actions from the VCF Operations Audit Events framework to provide a comprehensive, in-depth view of any potential compromise.

column3: Network oversight functions shall only access services (e.g. AAA, network time, software updates) over internally-facing interfaces.
column5: This is an architectural control that VCF/TCP configures by default. VCF/TCP's network oversight functions, which reside in the VCF Management Domain, are deployed onto a private, internal management network (VLAN). All their service interfaces, used for NTP, VCF SSO (AAA), and VCF Operations (software updates), are internally-facing on this non-routable network. Access to external resources, if required, is strictly controlled via the VMware vDefend Gateway Firewall.

column3: Providers shall use appropriately skilled and dedicated resources to understand and analyse security-related network activity. These resources may be provided by a third party supplier.
column5: While staffing decisions are organizational responsibilities, VCF/TCP provides comprehensive security analysis tools that enhance the effectiveness of security teams. VCF Operations for Networks delivers deep visibility into all network traffic patterns with automated anomaly detection. VMware vDefend includes an integrated Intrusion Detection System that continuously analyzes traffic for known attack signatures and behavioral anomalies. VCF Operations centralizes security events, performance metrics, and configuration data in unified dashboards that reduce the complexity of security analysis. These tools enable security personnel to rapidly identify, investigate, and respond to threats across the infrastructure.

column3: Providers shall ensure that threat hunting is periodically performed using available logging and monitoring data.
column5: While the process of threat hunting is an organizational responsibility, VCF/TCP provides the essential tools for security analysts. VCF Operations for Logs provides a centralized, queryable database of all platform logs, enabling analysts to hunt for indicators of compromise. This is complemented by the vDefend Network Traffic Analysis (NTA) solution, which functions as an NDR platform. It provides rich, visualized flow data and automatically flags anomalous behavior, allowing analysts to hunt for malicious patterns rather than just sifting through raw logs.

column3: Providers may outsource threat hunting to an independent third party, but, if possible, should not outsource audit or threat hunting to any party involved in operating the network.
column5: This is an organizational policy that VCF enables. VCF/TCP provides the raw data and tools necessary for a provider or a third-party to conduct threat hunting. VCF Operations for Logs provides powerful query and machine-learning capabilities to search logs for indicators of compromise. VCF Operations for Networks allows analysts to inspect network traffic flows to hunt for anomalous or malicious patterns.

column3: Asset management and network monitoring systems shall be kept up to date to enable security staff to identify and track down anomalies within networks. This shall include comprehensive details of normal system and traffic behaviour (e.g. source and destination, frequency of communication, protocols and ports used, and expected bandwidth consumed).
column5: VCF/TCP provides API integration support for third-party tools including IT asset management (ITAM) systems, configuration management databases (CMDB), and security assessment tools. To meet the requirement for "comprehensive details of normal system and traffic behaviour," VCF Operations for Networks discovers, analyzes, and baselines all network traffic flows. It provides a detailed inventory of all systems, their communication partners, the protocols and ports they use, and traffic frequency, establishing a verifiable model of "normal" behavior. This is complemented by the VCF Operations suite and VMware vDefend for broader security assessment and continuous monitoring.

column3: Network changes that could impact network security shall be notified to those monitoring the network. Monitoring processes shall be maintained and modified if necessary.
column5:
VCF/TCP implements granular role-based access control and additional authorization mechanisms to enforce access policies across infrastructure operations. Detailed logging monitors all changes. Integration with IT Service Management (ITSM) platforms enables change tracking and approval workflows. VCF/TCP maintains comprehensive audit trails for all configuration changes and supports rollback capabilities.

VCF Automation provides workflow processes that include change approval mechanisms for organizational change management requirements. 

vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) provides centralized lifecycle management for ESX hosts, drivers, firmware, and add-on software. vLCM uses desired state configuration to maintain consistency across infrastructure components and automatically detects and remediates configuration drift. This ensures all hosts remain compliant with approved baselines while providing detailed change tracking and rollback capabilities.

Change management extends to Kubernetes environments through vSphere Namespaces. Resource limits, storage policies, and access permissions require appropriate approvals before modification. VCF/TCP tracks all changes to namespace configurations, container deployments, and Kubernetes cluster lifecycle operations through unified audit logging. VCF Operations provides configuration drift detection and alerts administrators when unauthorized changes occur. This enables rapid remediation and maintains compliance with change control policies.

Platform uses Configuration Profiles, Host Profiles, and Image-Based Lifecycle Management to periodically assess host configurations. It alerts when drift is detected and offers automated remediation.

column3: Providers shall monitor physical and logical interfaces between networks that operate at different trust levels, as well as between groups of network functions (e.g. core networks and access networks).
column5: This measure is addressed by VCF/TCP's comprehensive network monitoring and logging tools. VCF Operations for Networks (formerly vRealize Network Insight) provides deep visibility into traffic flows across the entire platform. It can monitor traffic crossing logical boundaries (like vDefend DFW rules between trust zones) and physical/logical gateways (like NSX Edge nodes connecting core and access networks). This data can be analyzed to establish baselines and detect anomalies. In parallel, all firewall logs from vDefend (both Distributed and Gateway) can be forwarded to VCF Operations for Logs or an external SIEM for real-time monitoring and alerting on traffic that crosses these monitored interfaces.

column3: Systems that collect and process logging and monitoring data shall be treated as network oversight functions.
column5:
VMware vSphere provides comprehensive tools to track system events and user actions for monitoring and security. Basic logs are viewable through the Tasks and Events tab in the vSphere Client. This helps track changes and troubleshoot issues. For detailed analysis, VCF Operations for Logs collects logs from vCenter Server and ESX hosts. It offers advanced dashboards and analytics for deeper insights.

The VCF Operations Audit Events framework captures VCF/TCP interactions including user logins and logouts, capability checks, and configuration modifications across vSphere, vSAN, and NSX resources. This framework enhances transparency, control, and accountability by registering each action as an event. It enables detection of suspicious access patterns and policy violations while providing user accountability through detailed activity tracking.

ESX hosts maintain local logging with configurable retention and rotation policies for forensic purposes. vCenter Server provides database retention policies with automated cleanup based on age or database size. API audit logging captures REST API calls, SDK usage, and PowerCLI commands with user attribution. Storage operation logging tracks vSAN operations, datastore actions, and storage policy changes. NSX-T maintains audit trails for all network configuration changes including firewall rules, segments, and routing modifications.

Platform allows configuration of syslog to forward logs to up to three syslog forwarding targets using various protocols. Log forwarding supports TLS encryption to ensure confidentiality in transit. VCF Operations for Logs provides centralized log retention policies configurable by log type, source, and compliance requirements. Certificate lifecycle events including generation, renewal, revocation, and expiration are logged for security tracking. Time synchronization audit captures NTP events and drift corrections for forensic accuracy.

vSphere High Availability (HA) maintains detailed logs of all failover operations, host isolation events, and admission control decisions for audit trail purposes. VMware Live Site Recovery maintains detailed logs of all recovery operations, protection group changes, and recovery plan executions.

Kubernetes audit logging captures all API calls to the vSphere Supervisor. This includes namespace operations, pod deployments, and role-based access control (RBAC) changes. It provides complete visibility into container platform activities. Authentication events are logged for all identity sources. This includes successful and failed login attempts, password changes, and permission modifications through vCenter Single Sign-On.

vDefend provides Layer 7 traffic statistics with detailed logging of packet counts, flow statistics, protocol breakdowns, and CPU usage across cores for forensic analysis. vDefend Intrusion Detection System/Intrusion Prevention System (IDS/IPS) event correlation enables advanced event generation from custom signatures with detailed metadata for security investigations. This includes signature severity levels and threat categories.

Platform maintains comprehensive audit trails for all configuration changes and supports rollback capabilities. Change management extends to Kubernetes environments through vSphere Namespaces. Resource limits, storage policies, and access permissions require appropriate approvals before modification. VCF tracks all changes to namespace configurations, container deployments, and Kubernetes cluster lifecycle operations through unified audit logging.

column3: The integrity of logging data shall be protected, and any modification alerted and attributed.
column5: VCF Operations for Logs is a read-only log management system, protecting the integrity of ingested data. Logs are forwarded from components like ESX and vCenter to VCF Operations for Logs using secure syslog over TLS, ensuring data integrity in transit. Once in the log aggregator, access is controlled via RBAC, and the system is designed for append-only operations, preventing modification of original log data. Any attempts to tamper with the log forwarder service on an ESX host would itself be a logged and auditable event.

column3: All actions involving stored logging or monitoring data (e.g. copying, deleting, modification, or viewing) shall be traceable back to an individual user.
column5: This is enforced by VCF/TCP's access control and audit logging. Access to VCF Operations for Logs is controlled by VCF SSO and Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), ensuring every user is unique. Furthermore, all administrative actions on the VCF/TCP, including any potential changes to logging configurations, are captured by the VCF Operations Audit Events framework, providing an audit trail of all actions traceable to an individual user.

column3: Logging datasets shall be synchronised, using common time sources, so separate datasets can be correlated in different ways.
column5: VCF/TCP ensures this by enforcing time synchronization across all components. During deployment, all components (ESX, vCenter, NSX, VCF Operations) are configured to use a common Network Time Protocol (NTP) source. This ensures that all logging datasets from all systems share a synchronized time source, which is critical for correlating events during a security investigation. VCF/TCP also captures NTP events and drift corrections for forensic accuracy.

column3: An alarm shall be raised if logs stop being received from any network equipment.
column5: This capability is built into VCF Operations for Logs. The system is aware of all components configured to forward logs to it (e.g., ESX hosts, vCenter, NSX). If a component stops sending logs for a defined period, VCF Operations for Logs will automatically generate a "log source inactive" alert, ensuring the security team is immediately notified of the monitoring gap.

column3: Logs for network equipment in security critical functions shall be fully recorded and made available for audit for 13 months.
column5: This is a function of the log aggregator. VCF Operations for Logs provides centralized log retention policies that are configurable by log type, source, and compliance requirements. An administrator can configure these policies to retain all security-relevant logs for 13 months or longer to meet audit and compliance requirements.

column3: Network-based and host-based sensors shall be deployed and run throughout networks to obtain traffic to support security analysis.
column5: VCF/TCP provides these sensors natively. The VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall is a host-based, network-focused sensor that is integrated directly into the hypervisor on every ESX host, providing sensor coverage for all east-west traffic. This is complemented by VCF Operations for Networks, which acts as a network-based analysis tool by collecting and analyzing flow data from the VCF/TCP's virtual switches and routers. Together, these components provide the comprehensive traffic data, flow logging, and IDS/IPS events required to support security analysis.

column3: Access events to network equipment shall be collected. Unauthorised access attempts shall be considered a security event.
column5: VCF/TCP centrally logs all access events. VCF SSO logs all successful and failed login attempts from all identity sources. These authentication events are forwarded to VCF Operations for Logs, which can be configured with real-time alerts to flag unauthorized access attempts as a security event.

column3: Logging data shall be enriched with other network knowledge and data. In order to successfully analyse logging data it must be used in conjunction with knowledge of the provider's network as well as other pertinent data needed for understanding log entries.
column5: This is an organizational policy that VCF enables. VCF/TCP provides the raw data and tools necessary for a provider or a third-party to conduct threat hunting. VCF Operations for Logs provides powerful query and machine-learning capabilities to search logs for indicators of compromise. VCF Operations for Networks allows analysts to inspect network traffic flows to hunt for anomalous or malicious patterns.

column3: Network equipment configurations shall be regularly and automatically collected and audited to detect unexpected changes.
column5: VCF/TCP provides this capability natively using a desired-state model. vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) images define the exact software, drivers, and firmware for a cluster, while Host Configuration Profiles define all host-level parameters, from networking to advanced security settings. VCF/TCP regularly and automatically checks all hosts for compliance against these defined images and profiles. Any unexpected changes or configuration drift is immediately flagged in the vCenter Client, and automated remediation can be triggered to return the host to its known-good state.

column3: Logs shall be linked back to specific network equipment or services.
column5: This is a native function of VCF/TCP's centralized logging. All logs forwarded from components like ESX hosts, vCenter, and NSX Managers to VCF Operations for Logs are automatically tagged with metadata, such as the source hostname, IP address, and application. This ensures all log entries are directly linked back to the specific network equipment or service that generated them, which is essential for troubleshooting and analysis.

column3: Logs shall be processed and analysed in near real-time (in any case within five minutes) and generate security relevant events.
column5: VCF/TCP is designed for real-time log processing. All platform components stream logs via syslog to VCF Operations for Logs, which ingests and indexes data as it arrives. This enables near real-time analysis, searching, and alerting, allowing security teams to generate events from log data well within a five-minute window.

column3: The provider shall ensure that tools and techniques are utilised to support analysts in understanding the data collected.
column5: VCF/TCP provides a comprehensive suite of tools to support analysts. VCF Operations for Logs provides advanced dashboards, query capabilities, and machine-learning to help analysts find patterns in log data. vDefend Network Traffic Analysis (NTA) provides deep visibility and automated anomaly detection, allowing analysts to understand complex network flows and identify threats. For host-level analysis, vDefend Distributed Malware Prevention (DMP) provides detailed information on detected malware. Finally, the vDefend Distributed IDS/IPS provides granular metadata for all triggered threat signatures, giving analysts the rich, specific context needed for their investigations.

column3: Providers shall regularly review access logs and correlate this data with other access records and ticketed activity.
column5: VCF/TCP provides the centralized data required to perform this review. VCF SSO logs all successful and failed authentication attempts from all identity sources. These logs are collected by VCF Operations for Logs, which allows analysts to review all access, correlate it with data from other systems (like tickets or Active Directory), and build dashboards to detect anomalies or policy violations.

column3: Indications of potential anomalous activity, and potential malicious activity, shall be promptly assessed, investigated and addressed.
column5: While the formal assessment and investigation process is an organizational responsibility, VCF/TCP provides the integrated tools to detect, investigate, and address such activity. Indications of anomalous or malicious activity are generated by VMware vDefend's Distributed IDS/IPS, Network Traffic Analysis (NTA), and Distributed Malware Prevention (DMP) engines. To "assess" and "investigate" this activity, security teams can use VCF Operations for Networks to visualize the anomalous network flows and their dependencies. This is used in conjunction with VCF Operations for Logs, which allows analysts to correlate the threat with platform-wide logs. To "address" the threat, the provider can then use the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall to immediately apply a quarantine policy to the affected workload, isolating it from the network.

column3: Logging data shall be correlated with data within asset management systems to detect anomalies. Models shall be developed to characterise 'normal' traffic within networks, including type and volume.
column5: VCF/TCP provides tools for both correlation and traffic modeling. To address the first part of the requirement, VCF Operations for Logs can ingest and correlate logging data from all VCF/TCP components and can be integrated with external asset management systems via its API to detect anomalies. For the second part, modeling 'normal' traffic, VCF Operations for Networks (formerly vRealize Network Insight) analyzes network flows to build a detailed baseline of communication patterns. This is complemented by VMware vDefend's Network Traffic Analysis (NTA) and behavior-based detection, which automatically identifies anomalous activities that deviate from this normal baseline.

column3: Administrators should not need privileged access to network equipment to make administrative changes. Administrators should instead have privileged access to administrative systems (e.g. OSS) which make the necessary changes on the administrator's behalf. Administrative systems should group administrative changes to automate administrative processes and minimise administrator input and risk. When an administrator uses a privileged access into a security critical function, which is not an administrative system, this shall create a security alert.
column5:
VCF/TCP implements granular role-based access control and additional authorization mechanisms to enforce access policies across infrastructure operations. Detailed logging monitors all changes. Integration with IT Service Management (ITSM) platforms enables change tracking and approval workflows. VCF/TCP maintains comprehensive audit trails for all configuration changes and supports rollback capabilities.

VCF Automation provides workflow processes that include change approval mechanisms for organizational change management requirements. 

vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM) provides centralized lifecycle management for ESX hosts, drivers, firmware, and add-on software. vLCM uses desired state configuration to maintain consistency across infrastructure components and automatically detects and remediates configuration drift. This ensures all hosts remain compliant with approved baselines while providing detailed change tracking and rollback capabilities.

Change management extends to Kubernetes environments through vSphere Namespaces. Resource limits, storage policies, and access permissions require appropriate approvals before modification. VCF/TCP tracks all changes to namespace configurations, container deployments, and Kubernetes cluster lifecycle operations through unified audit logging. VCF Operations provides configuration drift detection and alerts administrators when unauthorized changes occur. This enables rapid remediation and maintains compliance with change control policies.

Platform uses Configuration Profiles, Host Profiles, and Image-Based Lifecycle Management to periodically assess host configurations. It alerts when drift is detected and offers automated remediation.

column3: The provider shall ensure that their critical, core and signalling security systems are highly resilient to signalling attacks. Signalling messages shall be validated at the logical edge of the network prior to being forwarded to critical or core nodes. Messages that are not encoded in a normal manner, or that are unrelated to a normal operation or call flow in the network, shall be blocked. All exceptions to this shall be understood, justified, and documented.
column5: VCF/TCP provides resilience to signalling attacks at both the network and host level. At the network edge, the vDefend Gateway Firewall provides protections like DoS/DDoS flood protection. Internally, the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall provides Layer 7 Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) to validate that signalling traffic is "encoded in a normal manner" and block malformed packets. At the host level, vDefend Distributed Malware Prevention (DMP) provides agentless, on-access malware scanning for the signalling workloads themselves, ensuring that even if a malicious payload is embedded in a valid signal, it is blocked before it can execute.

column3: A signalling failure for an externally-facing service shall not impact core nodes or security critical functions.
column5: VCF/TCP's Workload Domain architecture provides the isolation required to prevent signalling failures from propagating to critical infrastructure. Providers can deploy externally-facing signalling services in dedicated Edge Workload Domains while maintaining core network functions and security-critical components in separate, protected Management and Shared Service Domains. Resource pools, compute isolation, and separate failure domains ensure that resource exhaustion or failures in edge signalling workloads cannot affect core platform stability. VMware vDefend enforces network isolation between domains, preventing signalling traffic overloads or attacks from reaching critical management functions.

column3: With the exception of SS7 and GTP-C, only 'hub' signalling addresses shall be exposed externally. This shall be done in such a way that internal signalling addresses of critical core nodes are not shared or exposed externally.
column5: VCF/TCP supports this network architecture through NSX Gateway capabilities. NSX Edge Gateways provide Network Address Translation (NAT) services that allow providers to expose only hub or aggregation addresses externally while maintaining private internal addressing schemes. VMware vDefend Gateway Firewall enforces which addresses are visible to external networks and applies stateful filtering to hub addresses. This topology hiding capability protects the internal network structure from external reconnaissance while maintaining necessary signalling connectivity.

column3: Outgoing signalling shall be authenticated where this is supported by international standards.
column5: Authentication of signalling protocols is a function of the network applications (VNFs or CNFs) running on the VCF/TCP, not VCF/TCP itself. VCF/TCP provides the secure, isolated infrastructure to host these functions. It ensures the integrity of the workload through capabilities like VM Encryption and virtual TPMs (vTPMs), and secures the network path using NSX routing and VMware vDefend firewalling, including IPsec VPN capabilities. This secure infrastructure ensures the provider's authentication-capable signalling applications can run with high assurance.

column3: Customer data and customer identifiers shall be obfuscated before being released over an external signalling network, except where it is functionally essential to provide this information.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: In protocols other than SS7 and GTP-C, signalling network topology information shall be obfuscated before being released over an external signalling network, except where it is functionally essential to provide this information.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: All non-ephemeral secrets, passwords and keys shall be stored in hardware-backed secure storage. Where providers are not able to apply this measure to existing networks and services they must set out what mitigating steps they are taking.
column5:
VCF/TCP addresses this with a layered approach, starting with hardware-backed storage for the keys themselves. Physical ESX hosts, when equipped with a Trusted Platform Module (TPM), store their configuration encryption keys in this hardware-backed secure storage. For virtual machines, a virtual Trusted Platform Module (vTPM) can be enabled. This allows the VM's guest operating system to store its own non-ephemeral secrets and keys in a secure, hardware-backed equivalent.

These hardware-backed modules provide a secure root of trust for VCF/TCP's comprehensive data-at-rest encryption capabilities. Features like vSAN Data-at-Rest Encryption and VM Encryption use keys (which are protected by the TPM or an external KMS) to encrypt all data written to disk using the AES-256 cipher. This ensures that all non-ephemeral secrets, passwords, and data are protected at rest, and the keys used to protect them are also secured in hardware.

column3: Only physical hosts that have cryptographically attested to be in a known-good state can be provisioned into the virtualisation fabric.
column5:
VCF/TCP addresses this with controls at both provision-time and run-time. For provisioning, it ensures only known and trusted hosts are added using privileged access control and a mandatory, auditable manual verification step. Adding a new ESX host to the fabric must be initiated from VCF Operations and vCenter by an authorized administrator. During this process, vCenter establishes a secure connection to the host and presents the host's SHA-256 certificate thumbprint. The administrator is required to manually verify this thumbprint against the one displayed on the host's console (DCUI). This human-in-the-loop verification is the critical control that prevents spoofed or "unknown" hosts from being provisioned.

Once provisioned, hosts that employ a Trusted Platform Module (TPM) provide continuous cryptographic attestation of their known-good state. The TPM enables Secure Boot, which includes code signing and continuous verification of code integrity for the hypervisor and its components. These hardware-rooted integrity checks cannot be disabled, providing a persistent assurance that the host is running a known-good, unaltered state and protecting it from boot-level and hypervisor-level malware.

column3: Where the virtualisation fabric allows virtual functions to have direct access to the physical hardware (cut-throughs), it shall not be treated as a security boundary.
column5:
VCF/TCP supports hardware passthrough via VMware DirectPath I/O and Single Root I/O Virtualization (SR-IOV) for high-performance workloads. These "cut-through" mechanisms bypass the hypervisor networking stack, mapping I/O directly from the guest OS to the physical hardware.

A direct consequence is that hypervisor-level security services, such as the VMware vDefend Distributed Firewall (DFW), cannot inspect or enforce policy on this traffic. The DFW operates at the virtual NIC (vNIC) level, which is bypassed by these passthrough methods.

In accordance with this measure, VCF/TCP acknowledges that when passthrough is utilized, the hypervisor fabric cannot be treated as the security boundary for that I/o path. Security enforcement must be relocated to an external device, such as the upstream physical switch, treating the workload as a bare-metal equivalent from a network security perspective.

column3: Where possible, the virtualisation fabric shall be built and updated through an automated and verifiable process.
column5:
VCF/TCP is architected for automated and verifiable lifecycle management. The initial build is driven by VCF Operations using a standardized, automated workflow. For ongoing updates, vSphere Lifecycle Manager (vLCM), orchestrated by VCF Operations, uses a desired-state approach.

An administrator defines a single vLCM host image that specifies the exact software, drivers, and firmware for all ESX hosts in a cluster. vLCM then continuously checks the cluster for compliance against this image and can provide automated remediation to correct any drift. This verifiable, desired-state model ensures the fabric is built and updated in a consistent, automated, and auditable manner.

column3: Where possible, only automated and verifiable methods of configuration shall be used for administration of the virtualisation fabric (authorised API calls etc).
column5: VCF/TCP is an API-first platform designed for automated, verifiable administration. This is achieved using a desired-state model, where Host Configuration Profiles define the standard, golden configuration for all ESX host parameters. VCF Automation then acts as the engine to execute these configurations, allowing administration to be delivered via authorized API calls or as part of a self-service workflow. This model ensures that configuration is applied consistently, verifiably, and automatically during normal operation, fulfilling the "infrastructure as code" paradigm.

column3: Where possible, administration of the virtualisation fabric shall be automated during normal operation.
column5: VCF/TCP is an API-first platform designed for automated, verifiable administration. This is achieved using a desired-state model, where Host Configuration Profiles define the standard, golden configuration for all ESX host parameters. VCF Automation then acts as the engine to execute these configurations, allowing administration to be delivered via authorized API calls or as part of a self-service workflow. This model ensures that configuration is applied consistently, verifiably, and automatically during normal operation, fulfilling the "infrastructure as code" paradigm.

column3: Manual administration of the virtualisation fabric (e.g. access to a command line on host infrastructure) shall produce an immediate alert.
column5: VCF/TCP provides the specific logging and alerting capabilities to meet this requirement. When manual administration occurs, such as enabling the ESX Shell or a direct SSH login to an ESX host, the host generates distinct audit events (e.g., esx.audit.shell.enabled, esx.audit.ssh.session.opened). These events are forwarded to VCF Operations for Logs, which can be configured with a specific alert definition to trigger an immediate notification (e.g., via email or webhook) whenever these high-risk events are detected, ensuring security teams are alerted to this activity.

column3: Automated tools shall be used to find and prioritise events that require manual analysis.
column5:
VCF/TCP integrates security monitoring through the VCF Operations suite and VMware vDefend services. The VCF Operations suite includes VCF Operations, VCF Operations for Logs, and VCF Operations for Networks. VCF/TCP combines signature-based intrusion detection with behavioral analysis for advanced threat detection. Real-time system alerts flag security misconfigurations, configuration changes, and potential threats across the infrastructure stack. This includes policy violations, log data anomalies, and system health violations such as vSAN storage alerts.

vCenter Server provides a comprehensive events and alarms framework that captures thousands of event types across hosts, virtual machines (VMs), storage, and networking components. Administrators can create customizable alarm definitions with automated responses to security events, threshold violations, and system state changes. This native vSphere eventing system forms the foundation for real-time security monitoring and incident response.

The VCF Operations Audit Events framework captures VCF/TCP interactions including user logins and logouts, capability checks, and configuration modifications across vSphere, vSAN, and NSX resources. This framework enhances transparency, control, and accountability by registering each action as an event. It enables detection of suspicious access patterns and policy violations while providing user accountability through detailed activity tracking. Resource access control auditing tracks permission changes, role assignments, and access control modifications throughout the infrastructure, ensuring all privilege escalations and delegations are recorded.

ESX hosts generate detailed audit logs capturing security-relevant events including authentication attempts, configuration changes, and administrative actions. These logs provide forensic capabilities for investigating security incidents at the hypervisor level. ESX audit logging integrates with centralized log management to ensure comprehensive visibility across all infrastructure layers.

Platform supports native syslog forwarding from all components to external Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems. This enables centralized security monitoring, correlation with other security tools, and long-term log retention for compliance requirements. Integration with leading SIEM platforms provides real-time threat detection and automated incident response capabilities.

VCF Operations for Logs includes pre-built content packs with dashboards and alerts for security use cases. These content packs provide immediate visibility into failed login attempts, privilege escalations, compliance violations, and suspicious administrative activities. Content packs accelerate security monitoring deployment by providing tested queries, visualizations, and alert definitions based on VMware best practices.

Platform extends monitoring to containerized environments. It provides visibility into Kubernetes cluster health, namespace resource consumption, pod security violations, and container image vulnerabilities through integrated Harbor registry scanning. Network traffic analysis includes container-to-container communications with anomaly detection for cloud-native workloads.

VCF Operations includes rule-based and machine learning-based analytics for proactive threat detection and anomaly identification. VCF/TCP tracks configuration drift across all infrastructure components. Administrators can trace configuration changes back to specific users and timestamps.

VMware vDefend enables organizations to use custom and third-party threat intelligence. vDefend supports importing custom Intrusion Detection System/Intrusion Prevention System (IDS/IPS) signatures or those from third-party threat feeds. This enables tailored defenses against industry-specific attacks. Integration with Information Sharing and Analysis Centers (ISACs) such as Financial Services ISAC (FS-ISAC) or Health ISAC (H-ISAC) provides protection against targeted threats.

vDefend virtual patching capabilities allow deployment of custom IDS/IPS signatures to protect against vulnerabilities before official patches are available. vDefend signature bundle management includes version control, validation, and automated distribution across the infrastructure. vDefend multi-layer defense architecture provides comprehensive threat defense including IDS/IPS, malware prevention, and network detection and response.

column3: Procedures should ensure contingencies are in place in the event that further locations are added to the Schedule of the Electronic Communications (Security Measures) Regulations 2022.
column5:
VMware Live Recovery enables customizable business continuity and disaster recovery management in platform. Live Recovery operates on an ad-hoc basis or as part of pre-existing playbooks and runbooks. It supports granular recovery time objectives (RTO) and recovery point objectives (RPO) configurable at the object level. Organizations can perform non-disruptive testing through VMware Live Site Recovery and NSX integration.

Platform supports multiple protection methods and recovery types. Datastore groups use array-based replication, individual virtual machines (VMs) use vSphere Replication, and VMware Virtual Volumes use policy-driven replication. Recovery types include planned migration for orderly evacuation and disaster recovery for unexpected site failures. Live Recovery extends vSAN Data Protection capabilities for remote cluster replication.

VMware Live Site Recovery integrates with third-party storage replication solutions and backup providers through standardized application programming interfaces (APIs) and VMware vStorage APIs for Data Protection (VADP). It supports flexible network connectivity options to meet data transfer requirements. VMware HCX and the core VCF platform offer data mobility and replication options both locally and to remote targets. Changed Block Tracking (CBT) tracks modified disk blocks to enable incremental backups, significantly reducing backup windows and storage requirements.

Platform provides snapshot capabilities on a per-workload basis for point-in-time recovery of virtual machines. vSAN Express Storage Architecture (ESA) delivers metadata-based snapshots with improved performance over traditional implementations. vSAN Data Protection allows snapshots to be replicated and stored externally to the datastore with automated scheduling and retention policies.

VMware Live Site Recovery implements comprehensive disaster recovery capabilities through protection groups and recovery plans that organize and automate the recovery process. VCF/TCP supports bidirectional protection where each site can serve as both protected and recovery site for different VM sets, orchestrating failover and failback operations with customizable recovery plans.

Broadcom has measures for ensuring the ability to restore the availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident.
Additionally, Broadcom has measures for increasing the transparency of data transfers and associated privacy impacts. Broadcom conducts - and provides reasonable assistance for its customers to conduct - data transfer risk assessments in relation to the locations, especially non-adequate third-countries outside of the EU/EEA, where Broadcom and/or the sub-processors acting on its behalf may transfer customer personal data.  Broadcom transparently discloses such destination locations in the transparency notices of the relevant products and services as published at https://www.broadcom.com/privacy.

column3: The measures to be taken by the provider under Regulation 3(3)(f) should normally include ensuring, so far as is reasonably practicable, that the equipment performing provider's network oversight functions is located within the UK, and operated using UK-based staff.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: The provider shall retain a UK-based technical capability to provide subject matter expertise on the operation of the provider's UK networks and the risks to the provider's UK networks.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: Where data is stored offshore, the provider shall maintain a list of locations where the data is held. The risk due to holding the data in these locations, including any risk associated with local data protection law, shall be managed as part of the provider's risk management processes.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: Decisions about holding outside of the UK data relating to more than 100,000 UK subscribers, the operation of the large parts of the network, or the operation of network oversight functions, shall be taken at an appropriate governance level and recorded in writing. The sign-off for these decisions should normally be given by a person or committee at board level (or equivalent).
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: If it should become necessary to do so, the provider shall have the ability to maintain (as relevant, where it provides such a form of connectivity prior to the event) the following UK network connectivity for a period of one month in the event of loss of international connections: fixed and mobile data connectivity to UK peering points; mobile voice; and text-based mobile messaging.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.

column3: If it should become necessary to do so, the provider shall be able to transfer into the UK functions required by UK networks to maintain an operational service, should international bearers fail.
column5: Organizational implementation; outside platform scope.
